TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I inform the Senate that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins, will be absent from question time this week as he is overseas on official business. Senator Collins will be in Washington to make representations on the 1995 farm bill and the 1995-96 economic enhancement program and the dairy export incentive program allocations.

PARA.TAB: In Senator Bob Collins's absence, Senator McMullan will take questions on primary industries and energy, Senator Robert Ray will represent the Minister for Transport and I will represent the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer, Minister, to the terms of reference of the inquiry that you have set up since the weekend to look into the failure of the administration of the R&D tax concession scheme. I ask in particular: will this inquiry take into account the bungled guideline for the three other tax concession schemes dating back to 1988 which were not covered by my question last week? What are the sums involved? How many hundreds of millions of dollars are involved in the overall bungling of the four taxation concession schemes? What is the status of applications in the pipeline currently? Will the inquiry address the issue of failure of ministerial oversight?

—The inquiry to be conducted by Mr Jacobs, a former assistant auditor, will look at all of the issues relating to this matter. Obviously the priority issue to look at is the bungling, as you have referred to it—what I would call an administrative glitch—with respect to the financial guideline. The other guidelines that were tabled were in relation to legislation carried last year. But further inquiries by the department over the weekend have led us to conclude that they too should be examined. I make no judgment at this point as to their nature or their legal standing but at least we should examine them and do so thoroughly, and the inquirer will be asked to do that.

PARA.TAB: The second part of your question goes to sums. The sums involved are purely in the realm of speculation. I said, or at least my Secretary may have said before the estimates committee last Thursday night, that, of the applications disallowed during the period in which the guidelines had been untabled, there were 14 that had been disallowed. They amounted to some $70 million if the total all-up value is taken into consideration.

I am now advised that, in regard to four of the 14, the disallowance by the IR&D board was related to matters not associated with the financial guideline and that 10 were related to matters associated with the financial guideline. I do not have a figure as to what the total value of that would be, but I can assure the Senate that the legal advice I have is that, while no-one can be absolutely 100 per cent certain about this, nonetheless the very strong likelihood is that there are no financial claims on the Commonwealth. I want to make that very clear. The very strong likelihood is, and this is the legal advice, that there are no financial claims on the Commonwealth, but at this point we cannot be 100 per cent sure.

What is the status of the other applications in the pipeline? It is my intention to consider legal advice that the Attorney-General has provided me over the weekend, which my office has received in writing, I am informed, just a few moments ago. I have not read it. I feel an obligation to bring it to the attention of my colleagues at the next cabinet meeting.

The oral bottom line—and I assume this is reflected in the written advice; but this is what I have been given orally—is essentially that the actions taken by us were reasonable actions to have been taken up to this stage and probably would have solved the matter. The way of putting the matter beyond question is perhaps to bring down a legislative change. That is a matter for consideration and I will release the advice as soon as I have had a chance to draw it to the attention of the cabinet and to consider it myself.

In respect of any other applications, the position is that the IR&D board is acting without legal force at this stage. I have suggested to it that it continue meeting, that it consider the applications but not make a decision on them. When it does have legal force and legal power to do so it will then be able to more speedily consider those applications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the minister in due course table those guidelines so that we can see that the issue of failure of ministerial oversight is in fact included? How is it that you were able to come into the Senate last week and argue that the guidelines were valid when you had in fact gone to the appeal court and argued that they were invalid because of a failure to table? This is extraordinary. Will you explain to the Senate the morality of relying on your own failure as a basis of an appeal against a private sector litigant?
—Mr President—

—No, I am just going to answer the point. Last Thursday when I answered this question I was of the view—and I still am of the view—that the tabling of the guidelines that we had entered into was the correct course to remedy the issue.
—One of your grounds for appeal was in fact that they were invalid because you failed to table them.

—Because, at the time of the case, it became obvious—as I said last Thursday—that the guidelines had not been tabled and the proper processes had not been complied with. When the case came before us for consideration, an examination of all the circumstances showed that that had occurred and that created a basis, of course, for any argument the Commonwealth may have made. But the issue here, I believe, is to speedily correct what has been an administrative oversight and to do so as quickly and as feasibly as possible.
—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I ask: what is the government doing to contribute to the recognition of World Environment Day?
—Mr President—
—Do you think you will be able to answer that one?

—I will certainly try. Today is World Environment Day. I was able to announce this morning the establishment of a biodiversity conservation program—a $17 million program—which will help drive forward the implementation of Australia's national strategy for the conservation of biological diversity. I also would like to advise the Senate today that the Prime Minister has written to all state premiers and chief ministers to invite them to formally sign and adopt the strategy. Only Western Australia has refused to support our biodiversity national strategy.

PARA.TAB: The government does regard biodiversity conservation as an important environmental priority because Australia is one of 12 countries that is outstandingly rich in biological diversity, and it is the only developed country in the world to be classified as mega diverse. Biodiversity is also a genetic resource, which provides us with essentials like food, medicines and industrial products. These resources and their relative health also influence and determine rainfall, climate, the productivity of our soils, the ability of the environment to cope with pollution and the delicate balance of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.

Although Australia is rich in biodiversity, since 1788 we have lost about 50 per cent of our rainforests, 43 per cent of our forests and 60 per cent of our coastal wetlands in southern and eastern Australia. About 79 plant, 20 mammal and nine bird species have been lost, and 90 per cent of our medium-sized mammals are either extinct, endangered or vulnerable. This type of situation is mirrored right around the world.

Along with a range of other initiatives already in place, the biodiversity conservation program I have announced today recognises that the protection of our biodiversity can only be achieved cooperatively. The program will provide support for integrated approaches to biodiversity protection, including the implementation of bioregional planning across the country, joint projects with industry and other key stakeholders, incentive programs, and training.

The program also aims to add to the knowledge base on which scientists and decision makers rely and will include the development of an electronic information service called Biolink Australia. Support will also be given to a program of monitoring, allowing species and habitat changes to be measured and quick response solutions to be developed. Community involvement will be encouraged in the areas of information sharing, on-the-ground monitoring, the development of biodiversity education programs and in the establishment of a community biodiversity network.

Building on the national wilderness inventory, the program provides $3.9 million to ensure that the Commonwealth actions assist in conserving wilderness areas, and we will also be providing $1.5 million to promote and implement the principles of the biodiversity convention internationally. This program's aim is to develop an integrated understanding—involving scientists, governments the community and industry—of the importance of biodiversity protection, both nationally and internationally. It obviously is a very important initiative on the part of the government. I applaud all the state and territory governments, with the exception of Western Australia, who have joined with the Commonwealth to ensure this national strategy is a reality and urge the Western Australian government to do the same. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In the light of your budget's tax hikes on employers and its predictions that growth rates will not increase above 3.75 per cent throughout the remainder of the decade, how does the government intend to meet its five per cent Working Nation unemployment target by the year 2000—which, according to the government's own green paper, required growth rates of 4.5 per cent to five per cent for that target to be achieved?

—The Australian economy has steady and strong sustainable growth figures. We saw that in the quarterly accounts which came out just last week. You have heard the Treasurer say that we expect the budget forecast for this year to be reached. That is accompanied at the same time by low levels of inflation—and, in particular, the underlying level of inflation is extremely low. So we have the setting for a continuance of strong growth with low inflation, and, as we have seen, that is accompanied by high levels of job growth—the last job figures coming down from 8.7 per cent to 8.3 per cent in the last survey.

PARA.TAB: The expectation is that with growing exports, particularly in manufacturing areas, with the overcoming of the drought, and with all the other indicators—the high level of profit that is available for reinvestment, the surplus that we now have in the budget, and the long-term savings plan we have—the prospect of a figure of five per cent by the end of this century being within the grasp of the Australian economy is true; that is an achievable outcome.

If you look as well at the most recent international survey of the Australian economy, the OECD survey that was reported in the print media on Friday, I think it is fair to say that, broadly, it endorses all the points that I have made about growth in the economy, the direction of the economy and the level of sustainable improvement in the economy. As a consequence, as I recall, it broadly endorsed the achievement of what we say is there—the five per cent figure by the end of the decade. For all of those reasons we think it is an achievable figure.

Mr President, if you look at the amount of job creation that has gone on in Australia over the last two years, you can see that we are well ahead of the target that we set ourselves at the last election. At the last election we said we would create half a million new jobs in this term of office. We have already passed that figure, a year before the conclusion of our term. The indications are that we can succeed in lifting that much higher.

This must be contrasted, of course, with the policy-free zone opposite in which there are no plans or policies on employment and no policies, either, on the issue of managing the economy. In the absence of there being any policy statement whatsoever, one must go back to the record of the coalition when it was in government. That record is high inflation, high unemployment and contracting economic growth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the answer to that is, you wish, because the opposition seems to want to be the doomsayers of the Australian economy and use its gloomy predictions, as if they were fact, to try to scare the Australian community. —I raise a point of order. The question was not whether we are on track or whether the opposition's policies are okay. —There is no point of order.

—I might add in conclusion that since then we have brought down the Working Nation statement which has been hailed, if one reads the OECD report, as a model of active labour market programs. If those opposite read the full report and not just the bits that their researchers dish up to them, they will see that it endorses the direction of our active labour market programs.
—It says nothing of the sort.
—You asked me a question about it and I will give you a full answer. It endorses the active labour market programs, and that is another reason why we are confident on this matter. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The minister will be aware of claims by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry that the OECD's recently released survey on the Australian economy supports its call for greater labour market reform. Can the minister indicate whether Mr Spicer's comments regarding the state of the labour market are correct, particularly in relation to full-time and part-time employment?

—Yes, we are aware of certain claims by the Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr Spicer, reported in yesterday's Canberra Times. He is reported as saying that businesses have responded to the `inflexibility' of the Australian industrial relations system by employing part-time workers and casuals.

PARA.TAB: All I can say, particularly as minister for small business, is that we have had a very constructive working relationship with the ACCI on many programs. In this particular case, we think Mr Spicer has misunderstood the employment strategies and the labour market in Australia.

The fact is that part-time employment has been growing since 1978 as more and more workers seek flexible working hours. In December 1994 a survey indicated that over 75 per cent of part-time workers did not want to work more hours—over three-quarters of the part-time workers in the work force did not want more working hours.

That these workers, of course, can work the hours they want demonstrates that there is flexibility in the labour market and that they are the main beneficiaries of the flexibility. More and more women are coming into the work force seeking part-time work and they want flexibility in their working conditions to cover their family responsibilities.

Nevertheless, by August 1994 permanent workers still represented over three-quarters of the Australian work force—over 75 per cent were in full-time employment. So we think Mr Spicer misunderstood what the OECD was commenting about.

While he may quibble and others in the opposition may quibble about the OECD report and how it should be interpreted, the OECD report did not mince words when it came to judging this government's policies. The report described the government's Working Nation strategy as `the most comprehensive strategy of active labour market assistance that has ever been attempted in Australia'. Australia's labour market figures, it says, have silenced talk of a jobless recovery. Of course, the opposition wants a jobless recovery. It believes that it can win an election on the misery of others and it wants high unemployment.

This government got the country moving through the One Nation statement and through the Working Nation statement. As is now well known in the community, since the last election over 640,000 new jobs have been created in Australia. We have done that without ripping away the safety net which many of the ideologues in the opposition would love to pull away, including destroying our well-formed labour market and industrial relations system in Australia.

I want to point out the difference between us and America, which the `republicans' in the opposition clearly quote at great length in terms of the American Republican Party. They ought to just remember what the US Labour Secretary, Mr Reich, said last week. He said that the absence of such a safety net as we have in Australia in his own country had generated vast inequalities in income and wealth which in turn threatened the social fabric of his nation.

That, more than anything, indicates by comparison our success in this country. Of course, we do wait with great patience to see any policy coming from the opposition on what it would want to do in employment creation in this country. But I suspect that the policy-free zone in the opposition will continue endlessly until the next election—and you will pay the penalty as a result!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to the decision by several home mortgage lenders such as Aussie Home Loans to drop their variable mortgage rates. It seems the major banks are reluctant to follow this, even though the price of funds to them from financial markets has fallen by 0.9 per cent since January. Does the government see this failure of the banks to pass on the benefit of interest rate falls for five months as evidence of a serious market failure? Does the government agree with the finding by the Reserve Bank in its last annual report that the home lending market is not particularly competitive? And, what explanation can the government give to the three million Australian home borrowers as to why their repayments are about $80 a month higher than they would be if the home loans market was truly competitive? After all, this is what the government and others promised as one of the real benefits of deregulation back in 1983 when you took the step of deregulating financial institutions.

—I am aware of what Bernie Fraser said in the Reserve Bank report. The answer is that we have a deeper and richer—richer in the sense of more variety and greater potential for shopping around—finance market than we have had before, as a consequence of the deregulatory steps taken by the government. Clearly, consumers are wiser. They are turning to better deals and away from banks as the major organs of financing mortgages.

PARA.TAB: The move by Aussie Home Loans to reduce its variable home loan rate to 9.5 per cent when the banks, as a group, are around 10.5 per cent is some indication that this is a wider market and that consumers shopping around, not simply being bank orientated, can find areas in the market where not only is the rate lower but the conditions under which the rates are paid—the types of cocktails and conditions people can get—are different and more competitive, too. The AMP Society, along with Aussie Home Loans and a few others, coming into the mortgage area has broadened the capacity for competition.

The other thing that ought to be said, not in defence of the banks but in recognition of their behaviour during the last increase in official interest rates, is that the banks did not uniformly gallop off and push rates up across the board. Some did.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first time ever.

—That is a good interjection, because there is a more competitive market between banks and between banks and the rest of the providers of finance. This has meant that banks did not uniformly push interest rates up. Some did not go the whole distance and others found different ways of offering loans. That is indicative of a growing and competitive market. It is the government's desire to make the market even more competitive and encourage consumers to shop widely and well when it comes to looking for mortgages, not just taking the face figure of the mortgage interest rate but looking at the conditions that attend to the contract as well.

—It is true, despite all you say about Aussie Home Loans, that the mortgage brokers still have only a very tiny proportion of that market and their existence has so far failed to affect the dominance of the banks. I am interested in your saying the government wants to make the market more competitive. As we are about to debate the Competition Policy Reform Bill, would the government concede that, in order to make the banking industry more competitive, that ought to be one of the early priorities of the new Australian Consumer and Competition Commission and the National Competition Council? Should that not be an important priority?

—It is true that the non-bank lenders have a small proportion of the market, as the intermediaries have too. Aussie Home Loans got on the front page and led the bulletins in just about every form of media today. That is a good thing because one of the key issues is that consumers do shop and are effective when they have information about what is available. The information and competitiveness being offered by this sector is to be encouraged. As to your question about the new competition commission, I hope you are right—I am sure that you are—in anticipating carriage of this bill in the Senate when it comes through. I will refer your question to the Treasurer, whose job it will be to oversee the workings of the new competition commission.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Can the minister explain to the Senate why the Australian dollar has fallen 25 per cent against the New Zealand dollar in the last three years, including 13 per cent in the last five months alone? Is it because New Zealand has a current account deficit of two per cent of GDP, one-third of Australia's banana republic level of six per cent, and because inflation in New Zealand is only one-third the rate in Australia? Why is the unemployment percentage in New Zealand some 30 per cent less than in Australia? Why is New Zealand able to produce a budget surplus of 3.6 per cent of GDP without any resort to asset sales and is able to double the surplus within a couple of years? Why cannot the Australian government produce surpluses large enough to fund tax cuts, increased welfare spending and a reduction in public debt, as the New Zealand government does?

—I am pleased to see that the New Zealand economy is doing better. That is good for Australia; it is also good for New Zealand. I pay respect to it. We may have the first glimmer of a coalition economic policy. If those opposite want to do as New Zealand did, and engage in what is fairly brutal and basically socially unfair economic restructuring that throws thousands of people out of work without support, let them stand up and say that. We will then know where its economic policy is.

PARA.TAB: Three things ought to be said about the New Zealand economy, none of which are meant to put it down and all of which are meant to put it into context. Firstly, in 1994, the New Zealand economy was valued all-up in Australian dollars at $68.4 billion, whereas the Australian economy grew by $110 billion. So the total value of the New Zealand economy last year was $68.4 billion, but over the last 10 years the Australian economy grew by $110 billion. In other words, we grew at almost double the rate of the New Zealand economy because of the economic restructuring we had undertaken in Australia, which did not have the same socially divisive consequences.

Add to that the fact that several thousand New Zealanders in Australia are benefiting from our social welfare and unemployment benefit. If they returned to New Zealand you would have an unemployment rate of around 20 per cent and not the current level. A huge demand in the Australian economy for goods and services has been the major beneficiary driving economic growth in New Zealand. Therefore, New Zealand is able to benefit from the strength of the Australian economy.

I will go to some of the other indicators. New Zealand's economic growth exceeded that of Australia's slightly in the years immediately following the 1982-83 recession. The New Zealand economy then moved into a period of stagnation lasting almost six years. Between the September quarter 1986 and the March quarter 1990, the Australian economy grew by 16 per cent while the New Zealand economy contracted. Is that what Senator Short wants to happen here? Will we contract our economy as it did?

On an annual basis, a comparison of the December quarter 1994 with the December quarter 1993 shows that the Australian economy grew by five per cent while the New Zealand economy grew by 6.2 per cent. Comparisons in terms of employment are striking. While total employment in Australia in the December quarter 1994 was almost 21 per cent higher than 10 years earlier, New Zealand's total employment was only about four per cent higher. Is that what the opposition wants? We got it 21 per cent higher, and New Zealand got it four per cent higher.

Australian exports of manufactures, including processed foods and basic metals, have grown strongly since the mid-1980s. This growth amounts to 12.9 per cent, current prices, from 1986 to 1993 at an average volume increase of 9.4 per cent each year. Over the same period, the value of New Zealand's manufactured exports has increased by an average of only 3.5 per cent each year.

I could go on, but I can see that I am out of time. There is a sufficient case to say that, while one welcomes the changes in the New Zealand economy, in my view it is not a route that any civilised government would want to take. It is too brutal and too socially divisive. The growth that we have experienced and the unemployment benefit and welfare comfort we give is one of the reasons why the New Zealand economy is doing so well. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In prefacing it, let me point out that full-time employment in Australia today is still less than it was five years ago at the commencement of this government's self-induced recession. Unemployment in New Zealand today is 30 per cent less than in Australia. In view of New Zealand's strikingly better economic record than Australia's over more recent years, with consequential benefits for all New Zealanders, why did the Australian Treasurer last week and the minister today and in estimates last week describe New Zealand's extraordinarily beneficial economic restructuring as crude and brutal? Is not the real fact that there is nothing more crude and brutal than a government that seeks electoral advantage by refusing to make economic reforms that are desperately needed, as is the case with this government?

—We are making reforms by consensus and working together. They have made reforms by confrontation and division. Let me just hold up a few graphs. This line is economic growth in Australia; that line is economic growth in New Zealand. That line is employment growth in Australia; that line is employment growth in New Zealand. This line is growth of manufactured goods exports in Australia; the bottom line is New Zealand. Senator Short, if you want those figures for Australia, say so. We don't.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Trade: Japan and the United States

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to the current trade dispute between the United States and Japan. There are national concerns about this dispute. I ask: what is the government doing to ensure that Australian industry will not be discriminated against in any settlement of this dispute between the US and Japan? The benefits of Australian industry through our membership of the World Trade Organisation has been questioned in the past. Will Australia's membership of the World Trade Organisation help protect our interests in the resolution of this dispute? This question has been asked, may I say, by Senator Hill—and that had a lot to do with my writing this question. It is a very important matter, as Senator McMullan will acknowledge. International trade is of great significance to Australia—a view which the minister will no doubt vindicate.

—Our concern, the concern that Senator Cooney refers to, predates this dispute. In fact, it predates the existence of the WTO itself. Our concern has been that Japanese companies will feel pressured to buy American to placate the US government and avoid retaliatory measures and, in this current situation, that they will buy American to prevent the implementation of sanctions against Japanese luxury models—not at the expense of Japanese suppliers but at the expense of competitive third country suppliers, for example, Australia.

PARA.TAB: Last week I received a letter from Howe Leather, a very reputable and successful automotive component manufacturer in Australia. That letter provides a graphic example of why the government's concerns are well-founded. The concerns the Australian government has been raising about our trade interests in the US-Japan auto dispute are real, affecting real exporters and real jobs. The letter demonstrates that US government leverage on Japanese auto companies has closed opportunities for highly competitive Australian companies.

The Managing Director of Howe Leather, Mr Chris Heysen, wrote to me to express his deep concern that opportunities for Australian automotive components manufacturers may be further reduced by current developments in the dispute between the US and Japan. Howe Leather is an internationally competitive producer and exporter of leather for cars, specifically for luxury models. It is located in Preston in Victoria, which explains Senator Cooney's concern, and it employs approximately 450 people. It is a world-class company, adding value to Australian exports and generating jobs for Australians. It is the major leather supplier, for example, for BMW, but only a small proportion of its exports are sold in Japan. Further opportunity to compete fairly in that market is being impeded by policies of Japanese companies to buy from the US to prevent quotas or duties being imposed. Howe Leather has told me that one customer in Japan has specifically limited purchase of Australian leather to motor vehicles for export to Australia. For exports to the US and other markets, the company is being pressured to buy from US leather producers.

In other words, the US threat of unilateral action is already taking its toll on Australian companies as Japanese automotive producers are pressured to buy US to avoid sanctions being imposed on their luxury models in the US. This is a very important example of the reasons why the Australian government has made a request to participate in the WTO consultation sought by Japan on the proposed unilateral action. It is out of a concern to ensure that the Japanese market is liberalised in a non-discriminatory manner that we have indicated our intention to request participation in the WTO consultations foreshadowed by the US on the import restrictions to the Japanese market. It is not about taking sides in the dispute; it is about protecting Australian interests and the interests of companies like Howe Leather.

A solution to the problem presented by Howe Leather is not going to be easy because we are dealing here with the practices of private Japanese companies, not the policies of the Japanese government. On that score, the government—and most recently the Prime Minister—has obtained firm assurances from the Japanese government that Australia will not be discriminated against and we are confident at the government level that will be so.

With regard to this particular company matter, I have requested that our embassy in Tokyo draw the concerns of Howe Leather to the attention of the Japanese government as a matter of urgency, and also that the letter be drawn to the attention of the US administration. My purpose is to underline to both governments that this dispute is not just a bilateral dispute between the US and Japan. The manner in which they manage this dispute and settle it will inevitably impact upon other countries supplying the Japanese market—in particular Australia.

Unless the principle of non-discrimination is applied in practice, companies such as Howe Leather will face the barriers they fear, not the opportunities they deserve, in the Japanese auto market. With regard to the WTO part of the honourable senator's question, the Howe example is a classic case of why we need the protection provided to us by the WTO, and why we need it to be a robust and credible organisation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has painted a very alarming picture, may I say, of the situation. I know the minister tried to get to the point, but what is it about the World Trade Organisation itself that will assist us? What are the mechanisms of the World Trade Organisation that will help in this situation?

—It is only because the WTO exists and Australia is an active member of it that gives us the opportunity to be heard in the process of resolution of this difficult dispute. If the WTO is not strong, the major economies are less inclined to abide by its rules. It is a bipartisan issue between the major parties and the alternative governments, and these are the rules which safeguard the interests of less powerful countries. We are the ones who need the protection against the influence of the major economies. Our actions in pursuing our interests in the auto case in the WTO indicates a resolve to use all the avenues we can to safeguard our trade interests. It illustrates that the WTO can be an effective tool, although not a magic wand, in our armoury to protect Australian jobs and exports. I table the letter from Howe Leather which was the cause of Senator Cooney's legitimate concern.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. What was the energy use in Commonwealth occupied buildings in 1992-93? What does the minister expect Commonwealth energy use to be in 1994-95? How many Commonwealth departments have reduced their energy use and how many have not reduced their energy use since 1992?

—First of all, let me commence my answer my congratulating Senator Kemp on, I think, asking perhaps his one and only question of me as minister for the environment. Having congratulated him on doing that, I also have to say that unfortunately this matter is the responsibility of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. But, for Senator Kemp, he has done pretty well. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has carriage of this particular matter. However, I might say to Senator Kemp that, as the environment minister and portfolio minister, I have a very serious interest and responsibility—as do other ministers—to implement commitments that have been made by the government in relation to energy efficiency measures.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, my own department, as I have said, is acting, and acting strongly, on the commitments that have been made. We have used independent consultants to undertake a comprehensive audit of the department's energy use, including an estimate of greenhouse emissions from all the activities in this particular area. My department does have—if you are interested Senator Kemp, even though you have misdirected the question—a policy of purchasing star rated appliances. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. There has been a streamlined system for listing drug products on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. Can you inform me more about that? Also, why is there a special seminar on the system being conducted for sponsors of traditional Chinese medicines?

—I thank the senator for her question. In fact, the other day I announced the new streamlined system to be known as the electronic lodgment facility, or ELF, for listing over-the-counter drug products. It has been developed by the TGA in consultation with consumer organisations and industry. It is interesting to note, Mr President, that Australia has not only developed this effective model but has also developed the software that goes with it, while overseas countries continue to debate whether herbal medicine should be treated and licensed as medicine at all. So Australia is very much in advance of other countries with this system.

PARA.TAB: When the new system begins operating in a few weeks time, herbal remedies, vitamins, minerals and sunscreen products which meet Australian regulations will be able to be approved much more quickly and for much less cost. The TGA is to be congratulated for developing this system and the software. Indeed, both the system and the software have excellent export potential, particularly in South-East Asia.

The TGA will be conducting a series of seminars in major capital cities to explain the new system for listing non-prescription drug products. However, there is some concern that a few sponsors of traditional Chinese medicines do not perhaps have a complete knowledge of or are not sufficiently up to scratch on this matter. In discussions with the Chinese Herbs Chamber of Commerce the TGA is actually looking at ways by which it can increase information to the providers of Chinese herbal medicines. There will be a special seminar for sponsors in the Haymarket in Sydney this Wednesday.

It is of concern that over the last 12 months the TGA has intercepted three large shipments of traditional Chinese medicines when importers have not placed their products on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. There has been one prosecution, two shipments have been sent back, and one case is now being investigated. If we are to have this very important regulatory information, it is very important that all sponsors involved in the area get to know about this information, particularly as it will improve their capacity to get their sponsored product into the market more quickly.

The TGA seminar on Wednesday will explain the legal requirements for the import and supply of traditional Chinese medicines, and of course the offences and penalties for illegal importation. There are 25,000 over-the-counter drug products already listed with the Australian register, and these include quite a number of traditional Chinese medicines. A special committee has been established to advise the TGA on traditional medicines, including those from China. Herbal remedies, vitamin and mineral products are big business in Australia. We have always had a very good system, Mr President, but now we will have an improved system through ELF to make sure that the products are listed and that the claims about them are substantiated.

To help consumers when they buy these products, last week I also launched a brochure called Buying medicines? What's on the label for me. It provides very useful consumer information about products that are both Australian registered and Australian listed. It is an extraordinarily useful little document. One million copies of the brochure are being made available through pharmacies and health food stores. Those interested, including senators, can pick one up and find out just what information on medicine labels can be provided to buyers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Troeth this day, relating to the creation of child care places.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to comment on the reasoning that Senator Crowley advanced for my question regarding actual new places in child care. PARA.TAB: The point I would like to make about Senator Crowley's answer is that over at least the last three years, and certainly since I have been concerned with this portfolio, the government continues to make announcement after announcement over the number of new places that are actually available in child care. Whether this is part of an actual figure or this is just a constant overlay by the government and an announcement of places that do not indeed exist is something that should be brought to the attention of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that Senator Troeth has got confused because it just displays yet again a party without policy. This is the appropriation of the money towards the places that were promised. This is actually the keeping of a commitment. But, then again, for a party that has no policy, you would not understand that you actually have to have policy and then appropriate funding towards it. That is just a little beyond the opposition's comprehension.

PARA.TAB: This is precisely what has happened here. Instead of being critical, the opposition should say, `Yes. This is good. There is the money that is actually going to the issue. The funding for those has been diverted from long day care places, but there are certainly new family day care places. We are also fast-tracking another 3,000 family day care places.

Families who are requiring child care delight in and like family day care because it enables the children to be cared for in an atmosphere which is very close to being like home. It also enables flexibility, because family day care will enable more places for the nought to three-year-old group—small children and babies—for which there are some problems. If those opposite went out and talked to the community, they would discover that that is the area in which mothers and families are noting that there is not a sufficient number of places. They want the places to be available for the younger child in the family. This is important. This is what family day care is doing. This is what this policy is doing.

It has been announced that there will be 500 places for families in the rural areas with working needs and that there will be a flexible policy to plan for that sort of thing. It is important that people keep remembering that this is new funding for new places and that we are delivering the money to implement the policy. Policy does not get implemented without money. This is what our program has been doing, and this is what the budget has announced. As I keep repeating, family day care is an important provider of children's services and of care for children.

The area that can provide very well for this service and which will do a lot better than a lot of long day care institutions is the area of child care for children who are under three—the babies. These are the important things that have been done by this government in the area of child care. SPEECH.PARA: I shall now reflect on the content of those documents and why, in my view, it is essential that they be tabled. This return to order orders the government to provide copies of various documents which fall into three different categories: papers relating to the ATSIC board meeting No. 34; papers relating to discussions on the land fund between ATSIC and ministers and staff of ministers; and papers relating to discussions and negotiations on the land fund held between ATSIC, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and any indigenous land fund bill negotiators.

PARA.TAB: These papers are necessary because they will help clarify what is meant in various statements made in ATSIC paper No. 1849. These papers will help to identify the reasoning behind ATSIC's decision to set aside $20 million for the Northern Territory out of a total of $24 million available for land purchases by ATSIC over the next two years.

I will not go over the very lengthy grounds that we raised during the debate of censure of the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and Senator Bob Collins as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I need, for succinctness, to summarise why these papers are so vital.

In the past, on a number of occasions the government has come to the Greens and this place and argued vigorously that we should not support a return to order of papers. On all these occasions the government has argued that it always agreed to returns to order, except when to do so would be to breach national security or commercial-in-confidence matters. The only exceptions, according to the government, were national security and commercial-in-confidence matters.

This return to order does not have either of those concerns. The government is free to say that it is arguing against the order on that basis, but that is highly unlikely and should be questioned if that is the case. If the government does not respond positively to this order, all that that will do is confirm the fears of this chamber that the government really does have something to hide and that it may be frightened that the documents will reveal a deal between the government, ATSIC and a number of key Aboriginal organisations about the concentration of money on land purchases in the Northern Territory.
The government has yet to give any sort of explanation about the meaning of certain statements in ATSIC brief paper No. 1849. The first is:

SPEECH.PARA: There be special treatment for the Northern Territory for land acquisitions under ATSIC's land acquisition management program in line with discussions with government and the restrictions of the bill.
Another statement is:

This option contains the greatest difficulties for the parallel programs in that if ATSIC were to prioritise land management, the Northern Territory would have very little access to historical levels of land acquisition funding. The rationale for having parallel programs is therefore lost, which is the basis of the Prime Minister's agreement with indigenous land fund bill negotiators.
Yet another quote states:
The Northern Territory traditional owners would lose rights resulting from the rest of indigenous people gaining access to land acquisition.

If the government is unwilling to provide a full and adequate answer to this matter, I for one am not willing to give it up until the matter has been fully investigated. When these papers are provided, I will then peruse them with a view to further questioning ATSIC during the supplementary estimates hearings. As was mentioned during the debate last Wednesday, there were repeated attempts to gain this information from the government via these documents and also during estimates preliminary hearings. I hope the government will now take the opportunity to provide the papers so that we will not have to take up any more time of the Senate on this matter. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the motion from Senator Chamarette. I know a lot of this ground was covered last week during the ridiculous censure motion we had against the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and—
—It was successful.

—It was successful. Big deal! What happened? The world came to a shattering halt! The government does not wish to take up the time of the Senate, especially in light of the amount of time wasted last week. Senator Chamarette actively pursued the same subject matter in the estimates hearings on 26 May 1995 and has placed many questions on notice which ATSIC is now working its way through to provide answers.

PARA.TAB: The government wishes to express the following strong reservations about Senator Chamarette's motion. In relation to the general scope of information required in parts (b) and (c) of the motion, it is unreasonable to expect all the material covered by the motion to be identified and tabled within the time frame outlined in the motion. It must also be noted that some of the material requested in the motion would normally be exempt from release under the Freedom of Information Act. The sheer breadth of the material requested would require a major diversion of staff resources to fulfil, and one which the government is not prepared to direct.

I am also advised that there is currently an application before the Federal Court lodged by the New South Wales Land Council regarding ATSIC's decision about land purchases. The issues that may be canvassed in those proceedings would require examination of some of the documents being sought in this notice. Depending on how that action proceeds, issues of sub judice may arise. In addition, the government has on other occasions in the Senate indicated that it will not table high-level advice from departments to ministers, and the government will again not table such advice. On this occasion many of the documents contain matter in the nature of giving or receiving of opinion, advice and recommendations which is a fundamental part of the deliberative process of both ATSIC and the government.

In respect of Senator Chamarette's request for ATSIC paper No. 1849, the document was tabled by Senator Campbell on 11 May. If the senator were able to refine her request to particular documents relating to particular discussions between identifiable parties, the government would be better able perhaps to assist in the provision of documents. I understand that Senator Chamarette was not prepared to consider that as an option. The government opposes the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has basically gone down a path of ensuring the Senate, the parliament and therefore the people of Australia know as little as possible about the process by which it was agreed to set up a legislative structure that ensured that nearly all of the money available for land acquisition to ATSIC in the next two years goes wholly and solely into the Northern Territory and therefore creates a distortion and a corruption for generations to come of the assistance provided by the Commonwealth of Australia to Aboriginal people. The government has misled the Senate.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Chamarette seeks to do—and she has the coalition's support—is to find out how this corruption began and how this corruption took place under the nose of the Commonwealth parliament. I remind the Senate and you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that we thought this corruption was taking place. We had a suspicion that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was involved in this corrupt process that has actually seen a corruption of assistance—probably the first time such a corruption has occurred in the history of Australia and in the history of indigenous affairs in this nation. We warned the parliament and the government, `If you go down this path, this is what is likely to occur—that all of the money in the next two years will be put into the Northern Territory.'

As I said to the Senate, we have nothing against Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory receiving as much assistance as they can get, because there are significant examples to show that they need that assistance. But this Commonwealth parliament has an enormous responsibility to ensure on behalf of all Australians and particularly Aboriginal Australians that there is an equitable distribution across Australia of what is available.

I keep on saying—and I will continue to say it until someone actually reports it—that this is not a two-year problem; it is a 10-, 15- or 20-year problem. When you buy all the extra land in the Northern Territory in the next two years, you are going to, if you are sensible, ensure that money goes into managing it so that it does not just rot and so that the people who own the land do not just sit on a piece of land they can do nothing with. It needs to be managed—be it a pastoral lease, be it some other form of economic endeavour or, as Tracker Tilmouth has said, be it even for conservation values, or cultural or traditional values and not have any economic viability. You need money to manage that land. So I say to the government that it is not just a two-year problem.

The government's deception and the corruption of this process will ensure that there is a corruption of indigenous land moneys for generations to come. I do not exaggerate; I mean generations to come. It could be 20, 30, 40 years, if not longer, because you will have this massive distortion created by the Prime Minister and offered to ATSIC. We believe, based on the ATSIC minute that was tabled in this place by me, that there was some sort of deal. Senator Bob Collins said last week, `You think this deal took place at this meeting where all these people were.' We knew about that meeting. We had that provided to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration back in the latter half of last year. We knew about that meeting. We knew who was at it. We know vaguely what was discussed at it.

We all know in this parliament that when Mr Keating sets out to do a deal, or a handshake, or a wink and a nod he does not do it in a meeting with eight, nine or 10 people. He sort of did a deal with the press gallery, I guess, at the press club when he gave his Placido Domingo speech. That did not take long to get out, and I think the Prime Minister learnt from that. But we know that when the Prime Minister seeks to do a deal he usually does it with a very small group of people with very few witnesses. It is part of history that he sought to do that sort of deal at Kirribilli House. If honourable senators look at his track record in deal making, they will see that he had himself on one part of the deal, Mr Hawke on the other part of the deal and there were two witnesses.
