But our constituents and the Aboriginals of Australia will still be there, and the Aboriginals in southern Australia who are dispossessed as a result of this grubby little deal by this grubby Prime Minister will still be there.

Parliamentary Secretary, that is why it is fair that we reject your arguments about the so-called major diversion of staff resources. What a shame that you would have to divert some staff from pulling out some pieces of paper about this land acquisition decision by ATSIC. You have just set up two parallel land administration systems. We told you that if you wanted to save $3 million or $5 million a year, you should set up one land fund—called the ILC—with one board and one administration. So what did you do? You said, `We will have two for the next two or three years. We are so keen on spending money on bureaucracy and administration here in Canberra that we will set up two administrations to do an identical job.'

Absolutely brilliant! Sir Humphrey could not think of anything better. He probably would not even dare to try it. You came up with that idea. Yet you have the absolute gall and temerity to say that you are not going to send to the Senate these crucial documents to uncover one of the nastiest anti-Aboriginal deals in Australian history because of a major diversion of staff resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one of the reasons.

—I will go through the reasons, but I will knock them down one at a time. I will knock that one down really hard, and if it gets up, I will knock it down again. A major diversion of staff resources is not going to satisfy Aboriginals, particularly in the southern parts of Australia, who will have their dispossession entrenched as a result of this corrupt deal. They do not care about your staff resources. They know that you will spend an extra $5 million per year because of this deal.

PARA.TAB: The cost of this deal is $5 million a year. You could probably buy one or two stations in the Northern Territory with the cost of the administration here in Canberra because of this grubby deal. You are prepared to sacrifice the land hopes and aspirations of Aboriginal Australians to pay $3 million to $5 million a year in unnecessary bureaucratic expenses.

Australians who watch television and see the odd news report and who do not have any understanding of Aboriginal affairs and land acquisition—I do not purport to have much, but I understand a little bit about it—have this sneaking suspicion in their hearts and in their guts that we seem to spend a lot of money on Aboriginal affairs but Aboriginals still seem to miss out. They also suspect that it is probably because most of the money goes into the hands of bureaucrats. This has been reinforced in their minds because you have decided to spend twice as much as you need to spend in the next two to three years on more bureaucrats and not on helping Aboriginal people either manage their land or acquire new lands for their long-term benefit and for the benefit of their children and their children's children.

Let us look at the time frame argument. That is the only other one. I think the FOI act is so spurious that it is a joke. That the Senate, on a majority vote, cannot order some documents to be presented because they fall outside the Freedom of Information Act is a joke. That act has nothing to do with the powers of the Senate. The powers of the Senate are determined through the constitution, through the standing orders from time to time and through precedent as set down in the Senate. The Freedom of Information Act has no relevance to what we can order.

Again, the time frame really is a very spurious argument. The debate on the censure motion took place last Wednesday, and Senator Bob Collins criticised that time frame for the tabling of the documents at that stage. Early on that day Senator Chamarette made it quite clear that she would alter the time frame to ensure that it was practical. Senator Chamarette has shown on a number of occasions, at least to me, and I think she has said it here in the chamber, that she will be flexible about the time frame.

The government said, `We do not want to waste the time of the Senate, so let us stop trying to get all these documents'. If it had said, `Perhaps if you amended it for another 24 hours, we would be able to get you most of the documents and if they don't satisfy you, we could get you more', I am sure that Senator Chamarette, in her normal cooperative spirit, would have said, `We will amend our motion.' But Senator Sherry did not do that. He said, `We have got three reasons: time frame, FOI act, and a major diversion of staff resources.' There was also the business about advice between ministers and the department.

The time frame has been amended on at least two occasions that I know of. I know that we were not able to deal with the motion on Thursday and we are dealing with it now. Senator Chamarette is giving the government another entire 24 hours. Quite frankly, if the people involved in putting together this information were not working on it on Wednesday, I would have thought they would have been working on it as a result of Senator Chamarette's questions on estimates, would they not? I understand that many of these questions have been asked there. If the time frame is a problem, you do wonder whether the government is just saying, `No, we are not going to give you this information. You can do what you want.' I am very glad to hear that Senator Chamarette has said that she will not rest until she gets this information. From my own pursuit of government documents relating to some government dealings, I know that the government can be less than helpful.

The most important point that I would like to make is that it is all right for us to play a political game between the parliament and the executive in chasing these documents, but, ultimately, the executive will decide what it is going to give us. We can use all sorts of sanctions against ministers who fail to comply with these orders but ultimately the Senate, in its good judgment, will determine what sorts of sanctions should be applied.

This is not the outset of this process of seeking these documents; I should make that clear in this contribution. The outset was when Senator Chamarette sought information at the estimates. The debate on the censure was a further part of the debate on this issue. This return to order motion is another important part of it. I do not want this debate to conclude without people, and the government in particular, understanding the importance of what we are seeking and the importance of what this government has tried to do.

We have seen a prime minister take the Aboriginal affairs debate away from being, in many respects, a matter that had been ruled out of being a partisan debate. There was an incredible degree of bipartisanship in Aboriginal affairs. There were some points of significant difference between the parties, and there were some quite genuine differences about the implications of the High Court case in Mabo II—how that should be reacted to by the federal government and the various states. A lot of those were issues not based on racial differences but on the practical impact of the High Court's decision in Mabo II and how that should be implemented. That was used as a massively politically divisive issue. I guess the Prime Minister will blame us, we will blame the Prime Minister and we will not get much further on that.

I would like to contrast the debate over the Native Title Act and the land fund act with what took place during the debate on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation when Mr Hawke was Prime Minister. Those discussions generally were done around the chamber. They were done by—to use Bob Hawke's famous word that will probably appear on his headstone—consensus. There were letters written between the then shadow minister, Michael Wooldridge, and John Hewson, our leader at the time, between John Hewson and Mr Hawke, and between the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, and Dr Wooldridge, and there was a genuine effort across all parties to ensure that that Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, the processes and the formation of the council, were non-partisan.

Let us look at what has happened since Mr Hawke left the prime ministership and Mr Keating came in. Mr Keating, who had left this impression in the electorate of being a nasty, cold-hearted Treasurer, the man who had created the recession we had to have, the man who had delivered bad economic news to Australia for 10 years, had to quickly go out and grasp a social issue to show that he was really a man who cared. Having shown very little, if any, interest in Aboriginal affairs—I cannot assert that because I do not know enough about Mr Keating's personal background in politics, nor would I ever bother to read about it, but I suspect he had little or no interest in all the time leading up to his becoming Prime Minister—he quickly went out and grabbed this issue and used it as a politically divisive issue.

He then used what everyone knows are Mr Keating's political tactics, which are to bluster and claim that he is the one who thought of it, basically distort the whole process and use it for the crass politics of the New South Wales Right with which he grew up. That sort of politics does not work with Aboriginal affairs, I have learnt. The victims of that sort of political approach that Mr Keating has brought to the land fund debate are those people, as I have said, who have missed out as a result of Mr Keating's deal making from the New South Wales Right school of deal making. That is very sad.

This parliament has a duty to follow through with this, to find out the truth of it. As I said earlier, it makes little difference whether Mr Keating was the person who did the deal and who were the deal makers because ultimately it is important that we know the facts about it. It is important that the Aboriginal people who have had their dispossession entrenched as a result of this deal know what has happened. We need to ensure that, if it is possible to undo the corruption that has taken place, we find a way to do it.

Quite frankly, unless there is a full tabling of all the information that has been sought, if there is not an openness and a genuine willingness on behalf of the government and those in ATSIC who want to see justice done in relation to this matter, as I said, generations of young Aboriginal Australians will be the ones who suffer from this. It is an absolute disgrace that the government would seek to cover up and to hide the facts that underline the corruption of this legislative process and the corruption that has created this.

I urge the government to reconsider its opposition. I urge it to ensure that if this motion is passed it is complied with to the letter and that we do not have to turn this into some magnificent fight between the parliament and the executive. It should not be. All parties should decide that there has been a mistake made which needs to be corrected in the interests of all Australians. I do not just mean Aboriginal Australians; I mean all Australians, because all Australians have a big stake in this. It needs to be fixed and it can be fixed if the Senate knows the facts. I urge all senators to support this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I wish to respond to the words of Senator Sherry and Senator Campbell. Firstly, I want to talk about the importance of the issue. We are not, in this motion, seeking to begrudge the Northern Territory access to land funds, as Senator Campbell has already mentioned. It is the overwhelming disadvantage to the rest of Aboriginal Australia in terms of access to very limited funding for land acquisition and also management that is the chief concern; that underlies any implications that a deal was done between the government and any other people regarding the allocation of those funds.

PARA.TAB: The second reason for the importance of the issue is that we are expressing concern about the apparent capacity of government to influence decisions of the ATSIC board. The decision of the ATSIC board and the papers that were quoted earlier when I was mentioning the reasons for this call to order are the clearest evidence we have so far that some kind of deal and arrangement were made—not in any one meeting, but as part of the presentation of the legislation on the land fund.

The third reason why the issue is very important is that if the government continues to refuse to cooperate, as Senator Sherry indicated that it is refusing to cooperate, then it reveals a new class of documents to which this parliament is being denied access. It is not to do with commercial-in-confidence and it is not to do with security or national interest; rather, it is to do with some kind of secrecy over the high level of decision making in government. If that is the case, then the government needs to make clear where it is stated that this is not available to the parliament and why it has suddenly made this change in policy.

Senator Sherry, basically, gave three reasons for the government's refusal to cooperate with this call to order. The first one was that it was a wasting of time and was taking us away from the normal government legislation and program of this Senate. The only people wasting time are members of the government for their failure to respond to this request. The opposition has indicated support. The Democrats are not here; however, Senator Kernot made the point in her response to the censure motion that without reading these documents she was not able to make her decision about all the issues within the censure motion. I believe that there is support for this call to order from everyone except the government. In that case, it is the governmen's failure to respond that is wasting the time. It will continue to do so as it continues to refuse to present that information.

The second point Senator Sherry made was that we did not refine the list sufficiently and that this would take up a lot of the staff's time. The reason we could not refine the list is that we do not have access to the documents. Only the government knows which of the documents that it has refer to this decision that was made in which the ATSIC board eventually decided to set aside the amount of money—$10 million a year for the next two years—to the Northern Territory for land acquisition. That decision was revealed in ATSIC paper No. 1849 and in minutes of the meeting of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission board. We can only assume that there are other documents available. It is only the government that knows.

All we are saying is: you can refine it down to anything that refers to that particular matter and anything that involves discussions between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the staff of the Prime Minister, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), the staff of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, the Office of Indigenous Affairs and officers of that department and any other staff of the government.

It has been pointed out to me by Senator Tambling that I have omitted to mention any other ministers. When we bear in mind that Senator Bob Collins, while saying he did not know very much about this, had a discussion with Ms Lois O'Donoghue, it may be that I should have added the words `any other ministers', but I actually believe that, without amending it, we should ask the government in good faith to provide every single piece of documentation that is relevant to this issue. If it does not, then heaven help it when later on we find crucial notes which are missing that relate to the agreements and discussions.
If they emerge later on and this government is found to be in contempt of parliament by refusing to present them, heaven help the people that have been part of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly as Senator Collins represents Mr Tickner in this place.

—That is right. So if Senator Collins, as he often does, takes that role as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, there is no way of excluding him from that concern.

PARA.TAB: How the list is refined down is really in the hands of the government and its staff. We simply want everything that relates to that particular issue. We have no way of refining it. They do, they have the means at hand, because they can look and see which documents refer and which documents do not.

So we ask them to demonstrate their willingness to prove that there have been no underhand deals or negotiations. It is only within the government's hands to disprove the allegations that have been made in this chamber without as full an access to documents as we would like. It has been mentioned—I requested more information in the estimates process. We do need this information and it is in the government's interest. If it has nothing to hide, then it can simply provide these documents and prove that to us. If it continues to refuse to cooperate, it is only serving as an admission of its own guilt and I believe that is not in its own interests.

The third reason that Senator Sherry gave was that this goes beyond FOI requests. I think Senator Campbell answered that extremely well by saying basically, `So what? This is the parliament and it is really—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the Senate, not the parliament.

—This is the Senate and it represents the parliament of Australia. Since when do we need a freedom of information compatibility to ask questions on the spending of taxpayers' money which requires appropriation via this parliament? ATSIC is a statutory body, but it has no exemption from accountability for how it spends taxpayers' money. Therefore, it is perfectly appropriate for us to ask for this information and it is a nonsense that we cannot be provided with it.

PARA.TAB: So if the government is concerned about delays and time moving on, then the easy solution is to provide the documentation that has been requested. You have another 24 hours—there is until 5 o'clock tomorrow. And if you don't, then I am afraid there will be further wasting of time till the legitimate request of this Senate is acceded to. Otherwise the government will stand in contempt of the Senate and any problems in its program will be of its own making.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—The President has received a letter from Senator Kemp proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:
The Government's divisive approach to environmental policy which has meant that Australia's environment has declined in the past 12 years.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss the matter before the chamber that refers to the `government's divisive approach to environmental policy' which has led to the decline in Australia's environment in the past 12 years.

PARA.TAB: How appropriate it is on World Environment Day to have a stocktake to see, after 12 years, just what the Hawke and Keating governments have done to improve Australia's environment. The point I will be making to the Senate chamber is that, on a wide range of important key measures, the state of Australia's environment has simply not improved in the past 12 years. I will be referring particularly to the issues of land and water quality. But other important issues such as forest policy and greenhouse all show how incapable this government has been in managing Australia's environment.

There is a great irony that the Australian Labor Party has continually attempted to claim that it is the party most concerned with Australia's environment. In the last three or four weeks, as Senator Chamarette will agree I am sure, we have been literally buried in documents produced by Senator Faulkner and Mr Keating attempting to claim that somehow the Labor Party is concerned with the environment and is addressing the real environmental issues.

I put it to the Senate that the Labor Party is less concerned with the environment and more concerned with votes. As a result, it is a great tragedy that so much of the debate on Australia's environment—and the concern that most Australians feel—has been so highly politicised by this government.

Most green, conservation and other groups who are concerned with the environment are fed up with broken promises, false dawns and empty statements. State governments that of course play a major role in the environmental debate are particularly concerned, once again, that the Labor Party is walking away from the cooperative arrangements which were so painstakingly negotiated in the early 1990s. The Australian community, Australian voters overall, are fed up with the division and conflict which so often mark Labor's approach to environmental policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —This sounds like a recycled speech.

—You are embarrassed, Senator Sherry, because you know in your own state how poorly managed this particular issue has been and how two seats, possibly more, will fall as a result of your utter incompetence in this area.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Party's approach, as we have just seen with Senator Sherry, can be characterised by confrontation. It is driven not by environmental values but by politics. I put it to the Senate that the ALP has failed to focus on many of the key environmental issues facing this nation. In the last 10 or so weeks since I have been appointed to this portfolio, I have had the opportunity to travel to many areas of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tasmania?

—No, that will be coming up soon, Senator Sherry. I am sure that what I will find in Tasmania will confirm what I found elsewhere in Australia—that despite all the chest beating and boasting we see from Labor Party spokesmen, Senator Faulkner and Mr Keating, there is no doubt that on many measures the state of Australia's environment has continued to decline.

PARA.TAB: Vast tracks of our land are affected by rising water tables, salinity, soil erosion, excessive nutrient build-up, pest plants, feral animals and so on. Greening Australia estimates that some 60 per cent of land urgently needs repair and estimates that, nationally, some 250,000 square kilometres of productive land are lost annually through salt and erosion.

If you ask many of our students in secondary schools in the cities whether they are aware of the massive land quality problems which are experienced in this nation, I suspect you will find that many are not aware. Certainly, in regional Australia, many of the students would be. But as most of our people live in the cities, I wonder how many of our young people know the enormous problems currently faced by this nation as a result of land degradation?

This morning I met with a Landcare group from Western Australia. That group pointed out to me—this is an average, but it gives an interesting measure of what is happening in this area—that some two hectares of land per hour are being lost in Western Australia to salinity. Water quality in this nation is continuing to decline. Several times in recent years the Murray has ceased to flow at its mouth. Large sections of the Murray and Darling rivers have been beset by blue-green algae blooms; and the situation has been growing worst in the 1990s. I understand that the outbreak of toxic blue-green algae in 1991 in the Darling basin system was the worst ever recorded in the world. We continue to pour our sewage, often after only minimal treatment, into our seas and rivers.

The billion trees program was one of the Hawke government's major environment issues and has received considerable community attention. It is certainly a worthwhile program. But how many Australians know that more trees have been removed than have been planted since the program commenced six years ago? Estimates vary, but although there has been the planting of half a billion trees, there has been the loss of up to two billion trees. I recall Senator Chamarette saying at a Senate estimates hearing last week that, for every tree planted, 10 are lost. There will be some debate about the extent of the net loss, but there is no debate that there has been a substantial net loss since the billion trees program commenced. We are losing these trees by clearing land for housing and agriculture, and through disease and age.

It has become clear in relation to coastal policies, greenhouse issues, forest policy and biodiversity issues that the government is simply not doing the required work to ensure that agreements are reached and, once they are reached, that they are carried through. The forest policy statement demonstrates this. In 1992, groups in most states and industry signed the 1992 forest policy statement. The signatures were all there on the front page. It is worth recalling, Senator Sherry—and your state has an important timber industry—that since 1992 there has not been one comprehensive regional agreement completed.

I asked Senator Faulkner at the Senate estimates committee hearings, `Can you tell me when we will at least have one regional forest agreement completed?' This is three years after everybody signed on. Senator Faulkner gave me the truly devastating reply, `As soon as possible.' I said, `Give us some hope, Senator Faulkner, that "as soon as possible" may mean before Christmas'. Again came the devastating reply, `As soon as possible.' Senator Chamarette, I suggest to you that there will not be one regional forest agreement completed before the next election. The last thing Senator Faulkner and the Labor Party wish to do is make it very clear what their forest policy is—the party is so hopelessly divided. We will fix that up.

The blockade of Parliament House by the forest workers was the dramatic result of the Commonwealth government's failure to carry out the work required on the national forest policy statement. As I said, three years after the agreement was signed, not one comprehensive regional forest agreement has been finalised. A week ago Senator Faulkner launched, with a great fanfare, his coastal policy. That is yet more paper. In Senate estimates we found out that the states had not signed this policy. There is no agreement with the states on the vital issue of matching funding; and we simply do not know how the money will be divided among the states. There are so many things not yet determined, and so much time—(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate to be debating the environment on World Environment Day. However, it is rather ironic that this debate should be brought forward by Senator Kemp. He is the latest coalition spokesperson in the environment area. I have been the minister for only 14 months and Senator Kemp is the third person trotted out as the opposition environment spokesperson. He has taken on the responsibility, but the Liberals have shown once again their commitment to the environment by dumping Senator Kemp and the environment portfolio, absolutely unceremoniously, right out the door of the cabinet, to be languishing right in the tail of the outer ministry. Mr McLachlan, his predecessor, ranked No. 8—
—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Speaking about dumping, I recall that Beddall and Faulkner were dumped by Keating for Collins.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Senator Kemp, that is not a point of order; it is an interjection.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, I believe the minister has not been relevant to the debate. Who holds our environment portfolio has nothing to do with the debate. I suggest you tell Senator Faulkner to get back to the subject.
—I will give consideration to what you said; but there is no point of order.

—It really is ironic that Senator Kemp should bring this matter before the Senate today. The coalition has distinguished itself in this area, as it has in so many others, by its absolutely do nothing approach. It has a complete policy free zone on the environment. Let us look at the coalition's record on the environment. On the odd occasion it has made a decision on which way it might jump on a key environmental issue, the result has been pretty pathetic. Let us compare the coalition's record on the environment with the government's record. It is the coalition which supported the damming of the Franklin; it is the coalition which wanted to see the Daintree logged; it is the coalition which wanted the Lemonthyme logged; and it is the coalition which has rolled poor old Senator Kemp right out the door of the cabinet, so he is languishing somewhere in the tail of the outer shadow ministry.

PARA.TAB: It is the coalition which proposed in 1993 to abolish the environment department in the unlikely event it was elected to office. Its stance on issues such as forests, nuclear energy and greenhouse were described in 1993 by the Australian Conservation Foundation, absolutely accurately, as disastrous. That is the coalition's record. The environment is so important to the coalition that poor old Senator Kemp now has been caught in the job of shadow environment minister—the position is like a revolving door. He is probably the next one for the chop. In the 14 months I have been minister, I have seen three shadow ministers come and go. I do not like your chances, Senator Kemp, but I am certainly enjoying having you here while you last. It's pretty easy going.

I am proud to be here as the environment minister in a government that takes seriously environmental issues and its responsibility to protect the environment in this country. This government is prepared to make the hard yards on the environment and tackle the difficult environmental problems that confront the community and government.

It is worth reminding senators in this chamber about the time and effort that has gone into the ESD process at the highest level of government with industry and the community. The development of policies in the area show an understanding and commitment by the government. They have translated into significant environmental benefits for this nation.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you have a government that is willing to put its money where its mouth is on the environment. I know it is disappointing for the coalition that the government showed that level of commitment during the last budget with an increase of 21 per cent of funding for our environment programs. But it is something that really has been well accepted in the community. It is a real demonstration of government commitment.

Suggestions that the government's approach has at times caused division are a load of poppycock. Again, this government is committed to working with governments at other levels—state and territory governments and local government—with community and conservation organisations, with industry and with trade unions to deliver the goods. We have consistently tackled significant national environmental problems in a cooperative way. We have developed strategies and delivered on them in cooperation with state and territory governments.

It began with the national conservation strategy in 1984. It has developed since then. Look at the record; it is an outstanding one. There was the national strategy for ozone protection in 1989. Landcare, which was released in the same year, is one of the government's most successful programs. Again, it is based on partnership and agreements between the Commonwealth and the states.

In 1992, we concluded the national strategies on waste minimisation and recycling, ecologically sustainable development and a greenhouse response. Since then, we have had the national water quality strategy. We are well advanced towards completing strategies on weeds, rangelands and endangered species.

Today I announced again that the government is proposing to proceed with the signature of the national strategy for the conservation of biological diversity. Regrettably, as we often see in the environment area, it will be without the cooperation of the Western Australian government. It is a Liberal state government that reflects the Liberal Party approach to environment issues.

If Senator Kemp is so committed to environmental protection in this country, he should get on the telephone to the Western Australian government, ring a few of his conservative colleagues and encourage them to be involved with other state and territory governments in delivering the goods. Senator Kemp's comment in relation to the coastal package not being developed in cooperation with the states is absolutely untrue, and he knows it. He knows that it is not the case. He knows what the truth is. But he is very disappointed that this federal government has delivered on the ecologically sustainable management of our coasts and marine environment.

Senator Kemp is very disappointed that, after the RAC report, the Commonwealth has been able to do that and again put its money where its mouth is, as we did with Jervis Bay, the protection of Shoalwater Bay, the protection of the Daintree and as we have continued to do. In the hard areas, such as forests, again, we are really delivering on the conservation elements and objectives of the national forest policy statement. We will not be resiling from the level of commitment that we have shown and demonstrated for a long time while the opposition continues its policy of environmental vandalism pure and simple. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The paradox in today's motion is that, while there are certain things that the government is claiming, the only way that it can claim them as any great benefit for the environment is because the opposition has been so weak. That is the real pity of what has happened with the environment over the last 10 or 12 years. Apropos of that, those who look at the Hansard record will notice that Senator Kemp, who introduced this motion today, has only raised the issue of the environment twice since he has been in that position. On each occasion, he has talked about jobs in the forests. He has not mentioned the environmental aspects of forests.

PARA.TAB: If one looks today at his press release, one finds a lot of goody-goody things that individuals might do but no mention of what government might do. So we get no indication of what a Liberal government would do should it form government. It is against that background that the government perhaps looks reasonable. But that is not to say that the government's policies have been particularly good.

One might look briefly, for instance, at promises made in 1990. We reviewed them at the time of the 1993 election. Compare some of those broken promises with the way that the government has continued to behave since 1993. For instance, the Labor government promised to promote the case for the Commonwealth to be given increased powers to make laws with respect to the prevention of land, air and water degradation. It was also going to legislate using the trading and corporations powers to regulate the activities of companies that damage areas in Australia of national and international significance. On both those counts, the government has simply walked away from those commitments and chosen to hide behind an intergovernmental agreement with the states to really do nothing.

The government failed in 1993 to protect pristine areas and other areas of high conservation value. It still continues to fail to fulfil that promise. Five years on, that promise remains unfulfilled. In 1990, the government promised to give a major increase in funding for a comprehensive biological survey of Australia to be completed by the year 2000. As we remarked at the time of the 1993 election, the Australian biological resources survey has remained at the same level in 1992-93, rising only from $1.1 million to $1.5 million. It will take centuries to complete the survey at that current level of funding. That remains the situation today. While the government has been doing certain things, it has certainly not been doing enough. It is only in the context of the opposition offering to do less that the government looks at all good.

In the current budget, $53 million has been promised over four years. The government has promised to spend a very trivial amount each year on 37,000 kilometres of coastline. In the first year, this money is mainly going to groups to do work that is already going on, such as the stabilisation of sand dunes. I do not gainsay the value of that. But virtually nothing is going to tackle the fundamental problems that are causing coastal damage. Nothing is going into the major problems of sewage and stormwater outfalls. I note in passing that estimates now several years old suggest that it would cost something like $8 billion to simply correct the problems of the treatment of Sydney's stormwater and sewage outfall into the Pacific Ocean.

The amount that the government is offering is trivial in comparison with what is needed. I suggest quite deliberately that the money going to groups is really the present day version of the big whiteboard, which we saw Ros Kelly use to give money to sports groups. It is an attempt by this government to buy votes and not address the critical problems of the environment. I repeat that this government has stood back and deliberately hid behind the intergovernmental agreement so that it can claim that these problems are not its fault but the fault of state governments.

This government and the opposition have at various times both promised to use, and have used, those comprehensive constitutional powers, which I believe they should use. The government used the corporations powers under the ozone protection legislation, which was mentioned a moment ago, and, of course, Mr Fraser used the external affairs powers in connection with Fraser Island. So both parties have used the powers which are available to them to more comprehensively protect the environment. More recently, Mr Howard said he would use the corporations powers to revoke the IR legislation passed by this government. So at least in another area a Liberal government, if it should form, would be prepared to use that corporations head of power.

What we see here is that the government and the opposition lack the political will to use the powers that they have. I pick up on the wording of the motion, which states `the government's divisive approach to environmental policy'. I would strongly suggest that what we see is a lack of leadership on the part of the federal government in exercising the powers which it undoubtedly has and exercising them in a way which would allow the states to come along behind rather than simply washing its hands of environmental protection and then leaving it to the states.

In the area of greenhouse we have seen some woeful decisions made by the states, and this government has simply stood back and allowed those decisions to be made. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to oppose the matter of importance raised by Senator Kemp and to support some of the remarks made by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, who, I think, quite effectively outlined the government's commitment to both national and international strategies to combat problems with our environment. He made reference to the government's very strong record, since being elected in 1983, of protecting the environment and using all measures at its disposal to advance environmental issues and to try to build a cooperative consensus approach to those issues.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the success the government has had in that policy can be evidenced from the speakers so far in that we have been attacked from both the left of the debate—which I think it can be fairly said Senator Coulter represents—for not going far enough and for not using our powers fully enough, and from the right of the debate by Senator Kemp, and I am not quite sure what his perspective on the environment is, even following his contribution. But clearly the Liberals and the Nationals have a much more conservative view and a far less pro-environment view than the Labor government has.

It is interesting that today, World Environment Day, Senator Kemp of all people sought to introduce a matter of public importance about environmental issues because World Environment Day is a 1972 United Nations initiative and, as other senators would well be aware, Senator Kemp is very positively disposed towards the United Nations and international treaty obligations as a means of tackling our problems. In fact, he tends to talk about very little else, and that is why we were surprised when the environment was placed on his agenda and he chose to speak about it today.

World Environment Day is a recognition of the need for international cooperation to protect our environment and the need for everyone throughout the world to cooperate in measures designed to improve and protect the environment. So it is ironic that Senator Kemp—the person in this chamber who has on many occasions opposed our international treaty making role and opposed the use of the external affairs powers to promote national objectives—came into this house on World Environment Day to move a motion concerning the government's position and record on environmental issues.

Obviously somebody in the party room was looking for something to talk about today to prevent the racial hatred bill coming on for debate, and this was the best they could do. As I said, given the Liberal's attitude to international treaty obligations, it is ironic indeed, on World Environment Day, that they chose to pursue this subject.

There is a further irony in that the MPI refers to the divisive approach of the Commonwealth government. The one thing that is dividing the Australian community in terms of developing a coordinated response to environmental problems is largely narrow states rights responses to attempts to promote national action in dealing with environmental problems. It is the very narrow states rights approach adopted by, in particular, my own state's government, the Western Australian Liberal government, that has prevented major reforms and major initiatives in dealing with national and international environmental problems.

So it is interesting that we have had Senator Kemp and the coalition talking about divisiveness on World Environment Day when, in fact, it is their opposition to international treaties and the use of those external affairs powers and their support for states rights which have largely prevented effective national strategies for dealing with a number of our major environmental problems.

The WA government—as I mentioned, and I think Senator Faulkner alluded to—has failed to cooperate or be involved in a range of national environmental issues and forums since it was elected some two years ago. An example is the National Environment Protection Council, which is designed to pass national environmental protection measures. All other states, conservative and Labor governed, have participated in this initiative, but WA continues to refuse to participate. It argues that it is some sort of special case and that national standards do not apply in Western Australia.

Senators might be reminded that they made the same argument in respect of native title. This somehow xenophobic view that some Western Australians have about other Australians is a very worrying trend, and I suppose reflects the xenophobia that Senator Kemp displays towards anything outside this country's boundaries. But the National Environment Protection Council is a cooperative model with a states and a majority voting power, and all other states have sought to participate. The WA government, by its opposition, works against effective national combating of major environmental problems.Even former senator Fred Chaney has remarked:

SPEECH.PARA: This seems to be a case of ideology overriding both commonsense and our involvement as Australians in national issues.
So I think the small `l' liberal wing of the Liberal Party is very concerned about these developments and recognises the problem that this poses to effective action in environmental issues.

PARA.TAB: We have seen a similar response by the WA state government in relation to the national strategy for the conservation of Australia's biological diversity. Again, all other states have participated but, again, WA refuses to be part of that national approach which can provide a cohesive and cooperative model for tackling some of these issues. The minister is seeking to build a consensus and cooperative approach to tackling these issues, and I think we ought to give him and the government support in that approach, but we are prepared to use the powers at our disposal to protect the environment if that cooperation cannot be reasonably found.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this matter of public importance introduced by Senator Kemp because we all know that, despite the government's rhetoric on the environment, its view of protecting the environment and who is concerned about the environment is so narrow that it cannot see the wider picture. As a matter of fact, in general terms it could be said, to use an old phrase, they can't see the wood for the trees.

PARA.TAB: I would like to comment on what Senator Coulter said because Senator Coulter and the Democrats, and the Greens for that matter, would like to think that they and their parties have a monopoly over concern for the environment. I would like to just show you that that is certainly not the case. Senator Chris Evans talked about us complaining about a divisive approach and about the Western Australian government. Let me say that it is possible that people in Western Australia, who live much closer to the area of concern in their environment, might know just a little bit more about their environmental problems than either Minister Faulkner or many of the Canberra bureaucrats who tend to be making decisions in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our standards are higher than the national minimums.

—My colleague Senator Crane would know because he lives quite close to some of the problems that do exist in Western Australia. The government either cannot see, or does not want to see, the massive problems that have been created by drought, land degradation, salinity, pollution of our waterways, the proliferation of blue-green algae, and so the list goes on.

PARA.TAB: Instead of listening to the majority of Australians and tuning into what they are concerned about, the government seems far more concerned about listening to vocal groups who, rather than negotiate sensible outcomes, seem quite happy at times to ruin peoples' livelihoods in their quest for locking up Australia into yet more and more protected areas. Certainly we should protect our flora and fauna, but it is not the panacea to all Australia's environmental problems.

The listing of areas for World Heritage will not help clean up the Murray-Darling basin or South Australia's Patawalonga River area. Creating wilderness areas will not desalinate the massive areas of Australia where past land clearing practices have unintentionally created probably our worst environment problem.

Locking up more and more forests may give the government a warm inner glow, but it is not going to change anything unless we have policies which encourage the planting of many plantation eucalypts and pines so that we can virtually eliminate the logging of our old growth forests. It has been said already that even at the completion of the billion trees program we will have lost more trees than we have planted.

Quite frankly, the government's policy is simply to see what the greenies are jumping up and down about this week—with apologies to Senator Chamarette for the use of that term; I do not use it in a derogatory manner—and then falling in line. It is a big mistake on the government's behalf and it is borne out of the idea that the louder the group, the more money and attention it deserves.

I do not think that this government has yet caught onto the idea that practically all Australians care about the environment. It is not just a small vocal group; it is practically all Australians. Some few people do not care. We care about air pollution; we care about our oceans and rivers; we care about the trees; we care about salinity and land degradation; and we care about the disposal of toxic chemicals and radioactive waste. We care about the country we live in precisely because we love the Australian way of life and the country that we have to live in. We love doing those things that Australians have been doing for generations: going to the beach for holidays, camping in the outback, sailing on rivers, fishing, skiing and so on.

Australia just would not be the Australia that we know if it was not for our wide open spaces and our relatively clean environment. Yet all this is being put at risk by a government which thinks that the only people who care about the environment are those who identify themselves with the green groups or belong to groups like Greenpeace and the Australian Conservation Foundation.

This policy is divisive and it has resulted in the government ignoring average Australians who care passionately about the environment but whose voices are rarely heard. Who are some of these average Australians? They are the people who, long before it became trendy to look after the environment, have been composting kitchen waste, garden waste, and all the sorts of wastes that we have. They are the people who have been planting native trees and gardens on private land. They are the people who have been recycling household water and other waste.

I remember this vividly because I spent all of my early years living where there was no reticulated water. For some 15 years my mother managed to grow vegetables and have a garden purely on recycled water from our kitchen. That was a feat in itself in a fairly dry area. We have the people who voluntarily patrol our beaches and pick up rubbish; people who grow their own fruit and vegetables; and people who install solar systems. Those are the average sorts of Australians who have cared about the environment.

Of course, the unsung heroes of the Australian environment are the farmers and primary producers, without whom the landcare movement would be nothing. These people have played a very important part. Yet, despite all their efforts, these Australians are made to feel as though they are second class citizens; as though their efforts to clean up the environment are less worthy than those of the so-called greenies who seem to have unlimited time to travel all over the country protesting at whatever is the trendiest cause at the time.

In South Australia, one of the trendy issues has become the World Heritage listing of Lake Eyre. Worthy of protection it may be, but it is another case of the government and the bureaucracy marching over the wishes of the people who live in the area. It is as though those people do not care about the area that they live in; only people who live in Canberra can care for the environment.

I have raised the matter of Lake Eyre in this chamber many times. However, there is one instance that I would like to raise again because I think it shows exactly how divisive this government is on environmental issues. In March, representatives of the environment department were scheduled to travel to Lake Eyre to discuss the proposed listing with the local community. In preparation for the visit the local Uniting Church minister travelled 3,500 kms during the week leading up to the meeting to try and convince the people living on the stations that it would be worthwhile taking a trip to meet the bureaucrats.

A lot of work went into organising and preparing for this visit: airstrips were prepared, accommodation was organised and plans were made for station owners to travel hundreds of kilometres for the meeting. Yet this meeting was cancelled at the very last minute because the department considered it inappropriate to visit the area in the light of recent violence between opposing Aboriginal groups in Marree after the lodging of the native title claim over Lake Eyre.

What about the livelihood of those people who were affected by the listing of Lake Eyre? The price of their land has already been affected. I do not think it is an exaggeration to say that many people concerned are sick with worry about their future.

I guess in a way it does not matter that the government chooses to listen only to the minority groups and the vocal groups. If the government does not want to listen to the silent majority, that is fine, because I can tell the government that members of the coalition are listening to those people. We know that the major environmental concern of Australians is the degradation and decline of our land and water. We also know that the only way that the concerns of all Australians will be addressed is by the election of a coalition government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must congratulate Senator Kemp on sounding like a born-again greenie and for raising this important issue today. I do not regard `greenie' as a term of abuse; rather as a term of endearment, I would say, for people who have raised our awareness about some of the most serious issues in our society today.

PARA.TAB: I agree with the Minister for Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, that this is a very appropriate debate for World Environment Day. But I disagree that it is ironic that the proposal was put by Senator Kemp. It is very pleasing that he has put forward this proposal critiquing the government's record on environment issues.

It does, however, beg the question: would the opposition do any better? Senator Faulkner went through the very many programs that this government has introduced over the years. I believe that the government has been at least making some attempt to look at the issues that are of great concern in our community today.

However, as Senator Coulter also said, the government has been able to look good because of the opposition's appalling neglect of those issues. I believe that the Greens and the Australian Democrats would agree that we have also seen the opposition's appalling bipartisan support of the government in instances where we are watering down the federal government's responsibility and powers in relation to the way in which environmental concerns are addressed at state level.

The basic problem is that the environmental agenda, even as held by the government's portfolio here, is essentially addressing problems that our civilisation has created and represents bandaids or, at the more dramatic level, surgery—basically damage control. We should be looking at stopping the underlying causes of these problems rather than mopping up the damage that we have created.

I therefore speak against this proposal, even though I agree with much of the sentiment behind it. I agree that the government's divisive approach to environmental policy has been a very negative force. The government's approach has failed to lead to a comprehensive program of environmental protection and an ethos which would mean that all Australians fully embrace the need to protect the fragile environment of our planet.

The government has played off environmental concerns against genuine fears in the community about job loss. In many instances, these concerns are wholly unfounded. For instance, jobs are being lost in the forest industry due to increased mechanisation and an increased scale of operation rather than a decrease in the areas available for logging.

Many of us in this place are also guilty of whipping up division in the community. If we criticise the government for the way the environment debate has been handled, leading to unnecessary fear in the community, we must also acknowledge that this fear has been whipped up largely by industry groups and community based organisations and by some of us in this place as well.

I am not willing to support this proposal because I am not sure that this government is solely responsible for the environment's decline over the last 12 years. Its actions—its greenhouse, forest and wilderness policies—may have been a contributing factor but it is not the only one guilty of policies which have led to a decline in those areas. The pressure on the world's environment is a result of increasing levels of pollution, population and exploitation of non-renewable resources which stem largely from our civilisation's emphasis on materialism and a value system based on greed.

For example, the hole in the ozone layer over Australia, which is growing each year, is not entirely our fault. Greenhouse gas emission is an area where the government took a leadership role then turned away from making the hard decisions to support a more industry-driven agenda. The forestry debate has been highly divisive. However, the government has no monopoly on divisiveness, nor on responsibility for the decline in Australia's environment over the last 12 years. Let us all place on the record today, World Environment Day, our desire to work cooperatively towards resolving environmental problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to place on record my appreciation of a number of the comments made by Senator Chamarette in this debate on a matter of public importance. I agree with many of the things she said, particularly her final comment. I do not agree with the position she has taken in supporting the proposal—
—I am not supporting it.
—I beg your pardon. Her contribution was positive and realistic in analysing the issues facing us in protecting the environment.

PARA.TAB: I wonder where the opposition's spokesman on the environment is? Senator Kemp proposed this matter and promptly left the chamber. He had a wonderful opportunity today, World Environment Day, to indicate the coalition's policies. It is beyond comprehension that he would propose such a matter without using the opportunity to indicate to those in the community with an interest in this matter what the coalition's policies on the environment are. It is all very well to say that the government is not doing well enough; you have to indicate how the coalition's policies would improve the situation. It is totally inappropriate to come into this place and just criticise the government.

I want to refer to the federal government's recent initiatives, outlined in its coastal policy, which highlight how much consultation and communication there is with other spheres of government and with the community at large. The government has undertaken a comprehensive policy development process to build on the findings of the Resource Assessment Commission following its coastal zone inquiry. Its blueprint for change, Living on the coast—I note here that Senator Kemp has returned to the chamber—presents a complex task to be shared by Commonwealth, state, Northern Territory and local governments.

The Commonwealth coastal policy provides the means for the Commonwealth to sustainably manage its own coastal activities and includes a range of initiatives whereby all spheres of government can act cooperatively to bring about change. Where is the division that Senator Kemp and other speakers have talked about?

The initiatives contained in this policy were developed following extensive discussions with state and local governments. They are designed to address specific needs through specific action at the local level—no sign of division there. The actions focus on: community participation in coastal management; integrated solutions to particular management issues; increasing the capacity and knowledge of those with coastal management responsibility to assist them to discharge those responsibilities more effectively; and developing appropriate links with our regional neighbours.

I particularly agreed with Senator Chamarette that when talking about the environment you cannot talk about national policy only, much less about state policy. With environmental policy development we have to look across boundaries, be they local, state, federal, regional or international. That is why the coalition is so out of touch in its approach to the environment—saying that it could not do anything that would impede the state governments. You have to work across the boundaries. You have to work to persuade state and local governments to work together constructively.

The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, has demonstrated on a number of occasions that he will work cooperatively but he will also make the hard decisions, as he did with the inappropriate proposed development on the Hinchinbrook channel. That was a very hard decision for the minister to take but he was determined to get the balance right. Yes, he will cooperate with state and local government but he has the prime responsibility in that world heritage area.

I am very disappointed with the opposition's contribution to this debate. On World Environment Day we should not be talking about division. We should be concentrating on the serious environmental issues that face us here in Australia and throughout the world.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Capital and External Territories Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories, I present the report of the committee on draft amendment No. 12, Russell, of the national capital plan, together with submissions and transcript of evidence. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to present the report on behalf of the committee. From the title, honourable senators would think that the variation to the national capital plan No. 12 relates to Russell, and so it does. However, the inquiry goes beyond the rebuilding of the Defence buildings at Russell.

PARA.TAB: The committee visited the buildings, and I think everybody who had not seen them before was absolutely appalled at the conditions under which serving men and women are being required to work at the present time. That includes the inside of the offices, the parking arrangements and people movements around the area. You could not go there without being absolutely certain that it is necessary to redevelop that setting. The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works has already examined the proposals and recommended that it proceed.

The Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories has a different point of view from that of the public works committee. Our committee looks at it as part of the parliamentary triangle. It was a pity that it did not come to our committee before it went to the public works committee. The proposal is to demolish eight of the Russell Offices, to refurbish four of them, to build three new buildings and a multistorey car park, and to incorporate parks, walkways and other things. It will enable Defence to bring its employees into one area. At the moment, they are scattered over a number of parts in Australia. This will not interfere with the Campbell Offices, but it is proposed to bring those in other places into the Russell complex. The purpose of draft amendment No. 12 is to complete the national triangle. I want to refer to that in particular.

The concept at the time of the design of Canberra in 1911—Walter Burley Griffin's design—was that there should be a parliamentary triangle. But it has never been quite completed. At present, the base of the triangle is Constitution Avenue, which does not meet Kings Avenue and does not quite proceed in a straight line at the relevant part of the triangle behind the Russell Offices. The committee supported the concept of completing the triangle and believes it is important to be completed at the same time that the Russell development goes ahead. If it is not carried out now, it may never be done and the triangle will not be completed.

The triangle can be completed through Blamey Square to the apex of the triangle, with Constitutional Avenue being straightened and Kings Avenue proceeding. What the committee was very certain about was that vehicular traffic should not proceed through Blamey Square to the apex of the triangle. I find it remarkable to think that, to have a triangle, you have to have a structure which enables cars to drive around all three sides. If that is the definition of a triangle, I think we have our concepts wrong. It is possible to extend Kings Avenue to the new apex of Constitution Avenue and to leave Blamey Square without vehicles. It is an important ceremonial place; it is a place for people. It has its memorial, and it has ceremonial functions and pedestrian functions.

To proceed with the extension of Kings Avenue by means of a road on each side of Blamey Square through to the junction with Constitution Avenue would destroy Blamey Square completely. I do not accept that it is necessary to have vehicles roaring around all three sides of the triangle to have it visually completed. It can be completed but with cars going off from these roads at other places.

The committee was of the view that the movement of motor traffic through the square was in conflict with its memorial, ceremonial and other pedestrian functions. The committee quite clearly recommends in its report that Blamey Square not be opened to through motor traffic and that it be developed as a people's place. It would add to its ceremonial aspects and its symbolism and if we proceeded in this fashion it would enable the parks down by the river to be linked up through Russell.

We were also concerned about the location and height of the proposed Defence buildings—the two new main buildings to be built near the apex of the triangle. The committee has recommended that the location and height of the buildings not detract from the backdrop of the hills. It seemed very clear to us that the buildings should be stepped sufficiently to allow the apex of the triangle and the hills to be observed from Kings Avenue as it proceeds into that area. It will undoubtedly result in some modification to the designs. We are talking about something that is pretty important. As I said at the beginning, we are not just talking about new offices for the Department of Defence, absolutely important though they may be. We are talking about completing Griffin's vision of the parliamentary triangle.

The NCPA argued that detailed design and specification of this area could not be given to us at present. We had made complaints about lack of specific information being given to us about the development of the apex of the triangle. We found it unsatisfactory that we were being asked to approve something without more detail. The fact is that what we recommend to the parliament is very likely to be accepted, and I certainly hope it will be accepted by the parliament. But if you approve of something that is not fairly completely designed, any one of us as a senator is likely to get representations later on saying, `What did you agree to that for?' We have to be very careful of what we are approving and require that more detail be given to us. It has happened with other variations to the city plan that have been given to the committee. I think we need more detail when we are doing these things.

You might be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, of a proposal to make this area a northern gateway entrance to the national capital. The proposed Majura Parkway would link through Northcott Drive, forming a northern gateway to Canberra and the national triangle.

TALK.START.PARA: —A $500 million project.

—It may well be a $500 million project and it may well go ahead one day. We are not suggesting right now that that should happen, of course. We have to think sufficiently far ahead not to block off the options that might enable that to happen. Another group of senators sitting in this place in years to come may well decide that that is what should happen and that it is desirable to proceed with the northern gateway. We would say, `Don't block off your options as to what can happen.'

PARA.TAB: It is quite possible to do what we are suggesting and redirect the traffic so that it does not go through Blamey Square but around the apex of the triangle and off down to other roads in the area. This can be achieved with a little bit of ingenuity, if you are committed to the concept of a people's place and a ceremonial place in the midst of the area rather than being committed to the mighty motor vehicle having free range to roar around all three sides of the triangle. I repeat what I said earlier: I reject the concept that you have to have motor vehicles traversing all three sides of the triangle for it to be a triangle. It can be visually quite complete without.

There is a lot in the report and I hope honourable senators will read it. I believe that if the objectives of what we have recommended are achieved, people and visitors to the parliamentary zone in the future will see the area that more reflects the importance of the national capital and the concept of the parliamentary triangle that Griffin sketched in the first place when he drew up his plans.

The committee is indebted to the many individuals, community groups and professional groups who took the trouble to give evidence to us, not just on the Russell buildings but on the wider interests as well. The committee is particularly indebted to Cheryl Samuels, the inquiry secretary. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on record some of my reservations about the report of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories, with which I concurred with some reluctance. Senator Reid talked about Griffin's original plan for the national triangle. As far as I am aware, that did not require the Department of Defence to be at one of the apexes of the triangle. I do not believe that Defence is such an important department compared to all the other departments in the Commonwealth Public Service that it should have pride of place at one of the three apexes of the triangle and so dominate that corner of Canberra by this plan. I put that general reservation of principle on the record. As far as I am concerned, Defence could be brought together in another part of Canberra just as easily.

PARA.TAB: Apart from that, the plans for all these buildings to house large numbers of staff do restrict the planning of the whole area. I emphasise that I am as much in support as anybody of the staff getting improved accommodation. Having examined some of the buildings at the existing Russell offices, I know that some of the conditions are appalling. They do deserve better accommodation. It is a pity to have the waste of pulling down buildings which were built only 20, or 30 at the most, years ago and which I would point out have been approved by previous parliamentary committees. I have reluctance about that sort of waste. I would emphasise that, having looked at the buildings, they do provide poor accommodation. There is a justification for improving the accommodation of people who have to work there.

One of the problems about the whole design issue is this emphasis on Blamey Square, as Senator Reid mentioned. All the requirements of the change of plan are based on insisting that Blamey Square continue in the exact place that it is. I am not opposed to having a ceremonial square. The problem is that its existing location limits the options for the whole area. I would have preferred to have marginally relocated Blamey Square so as to provide the necessary very occasionally used ceremonial place but not to pre-empt other design necessities.

I agree with Senator Reid about not planning everything depending on motor vehicles. I do not equate planning transport corridors with necessarily having to have them for cars. It is important to plan transport corridors, whether they be for traditional trains, light rail or other forms of public transport. Those things can, of course, be provided and they do not have to be provided just for cars. The problem, as Senator Reid alluded to, is the potential future plan to have a new gateway into Canberra from the north coming virtually through the middle of the Russell area. I think anybody who has tried to traverse Northbourne Avenue in busy periods would appreciate that there probably does need, in the future anyway, to be an alternative way into Canberra other than through the middle of Civic.

It is important to keep the options open for this northern gateway. The problem is that this plan for the Department of Defence at Russell does pre-empt future plans quite substantially in that there is the location of Blamey Square; there is the planning of the two major buildings not in my mind giving sufficiently wide space between them for a future transport corridor. I think it is a pity that the long-term planning was not decided in advance of this plan for Russell.

The other reservation is the issue of the view of the hills from Kings Avenue being interfered with by the substantially larger buildings that are proposed than are presently on the Russell site. So I emphasise these reservations that I had and mention that, while I did not go to the extent of putting in a dissenting report, it was with some reluctance that I agreed with this plan, and, while I concur with completing the national triangle, I am sad that it is the defence department that is so dominating this particular apex of it.
