TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee on psychotherapeutic medication in Australia, together with submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I am pleased to table the Senate Community Affairs Committee report on psychotherapeutic medication in Australia. This report has been dedicated to the memory of our colleague Senator Olive Zakharov, who sadly passed away last year after a motor vehicle accident. Her photograph is incorporated in the report itself. Olive was Chair of the then Standing Committee on Community Affairs when this reference was made in October 1992. She worked with great personal commitment and enthusiasm on this project, both in her position as Chair and later as a member of the new references committee. Having been a psychologist herself, she was acutely aware of the many problems which beset those people in our society with mental illness and the families and friends who care for them. Sadly, Olive did not see the report completed, but she did progress it to its final draft form and of that achievement she can be justly proud.

PARA.TAB: I am sure Olive would agree that the timing of the tabling of this report is particularly auspicious. Two weeks ago it was Schizophrenia Awareness Week—a time to reflect upon our own attitudes to the mentally ill and particularly the support such sufferers need to deal with their turbulent, disturbing, distressing and unpredictable lives.

The committee received nearly 50 submissions from organisations and carers of mentally ill people. Many of the stories from families were particularly disturbing, but throughout each submission several common issues emerged. The first was that there is an increasing concern in Australia about the extensive use of psychotherapeutic drugs. People believe that there is too much emphasis on treatment of mental illness through medication, either because there is too little alternative treatment available, or too few medical practitioners are completely aware of the alternatives, or the cost of alternative treatments are prohibitive.

Many groups felt that there is too little research into the side effects of psychotherapeutic drugs. A number of expert groups felt that there is too little knowledge of the range of drugs available and the efficacy of each in treating various symptoms and that there is not enough evidence of the long-term effects of various medications available. Many people felt that the general practitioner, who most often is the first point of contact for people with mental illness, is so often ill prepared to deal with it because of the unavailability of literature or the educational aspects of the medications.

Pharmacists drew special attention to `grocery list' prescribing—cases where polypharmacy `cocktails' are prescribed, sometimes unbeknown to GPs of patients with mental illness—cases where casual prescribing of medication has led to addiction and severe side effects and cases where patients have hoarded medication and self prescribed with disastrous effects or have not informed their GP about other drugs or medications they may be taking.

People gave examples of many adverse reactions to particular drugs due to improper diagnosis or inadequate prescribing and felt that so often these reactions go unreported. The issue of the use of drugs to restrain patients in institutional care was also raised by a number of submissions, with one citing Article 11 of the Human Rights Convention, that `Medication must be used only for therapeutic purposes and that it should never be administered as a punishment or for the convenience of others'.

There were calls for investigations into the legal rights of patients, the liabilities of manufacturers and medical practitioners, legal test cases and the operation of the Trade Practices Act in relation to the use of psychotherapeutic drugs. Nevertheless, despite the many reservations expressed about psychotherapeutic medications, many submissions supported the positive elements of medications under the right circumstances—examples of correct diagnosis and treatment obviously giving enormous benefit and enabling people to lead fulfilling lives.

The major findings of the committee in this report were not to undertake detailed research but rather to identify some of the most obvious problems concerning the use of psychotherapeutic medication and to consider these in relation to the needs of individuals and groups within the community in general. Our major findings included first a paucity of data and information; secondly, deficiencies in service provision to particular need groups; and, thirdly, a lack of empowerment of patients and advocacy services.

In the light of the submissions received from patients, carers and expert groups, the committee found primarily the data and information on mental illness to be severely lacking. This includes information about the psychotherapeutic drugs themselves, information and guidelines available to medical

SPEECH.PARA: practitioners, information given to patients and carers, and information available to policy makers and government funding programs.

PARA.TAB: Available estimates of expenditure on mental health services are essentially just that—estimates! The data available on medication use has a number of efficiencies which affect the capacity to calculate amounts and costs of drugs used, both in the community and those provided through hospitals. The Pharmacy Guild, the Health insurance Commission and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee all collect information on medication and drug use. However, at this point there appears to be limited information available on the appropriateness of certain drugs for the individual and their condition; the long-term monitoring of the patient; the side effects of these drugs; steps taken to minimise side effects; the variety of drugs; the quantity of drugs being prescribed; and the reasons for prescription or not of some drugs—whether they are available on the PBS, the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, or available at high cost or whether there is no alternative.

General practitioners lack information about alternative therapies and services, thereby overemphasising chemical and medical solutions. Anecdotal evidence says that they often under or overprescribe drugs for mental illness. GPs lack quantity independent information about psychotherapeutic drugs. There are no clear independent user friendly guidelines for the use of such drugs. Guidelines exist but they are usually produced by the drug companies themselves. The committee found that there was a lack of definition of `serious' and `less serious' psychiatric illness which hindered consideration of the types of services, therapies, medication, et cetera needed, either in residential care or in the community.

The lack of reporting of serious and less serious mental illness also challenges the accuracy of any figures in relation to the incidence of mental illness in Australia. Effective planning requires a more focused approach to needs identification and assessment. The fact that so many people in the Australian community are on psychotherapeutic medication suggests the existence of health and social problems. The problem of possible excessive use of medication may become more serious and more costly to the individual and the community if there is no proper assessment of medication and no provision of alternative therapies. In some cases medication may be less beneficial than other services and in others it may not be required at all.

The task is clearly one which should be addressed by the relevant Commonwealth and state or territory bodies as part of the implementation of the national mental health policy. Evidence to the committee indicated that there were several areas where prescription and the use of psychotherapeutic medication needed to be monitored more strictly. The committee does not consider it has received sufficient evidence to make definitive conclusions about the appropriateness of some prescribing practices. However, it considers that the information it has received does suggest there is a need for systematic evaluation of prescribing practices.

The committee believes that prescription patterns and the high level of prescriptions written for the concessional populations merit study by an appropriately qualified group. There may be good reasons for the prescription of a substantial part of the psychotherapeutic medication being used by the Australian population, but let us investigate the matter properly.

On the basis of the information received by the committee, it recommends a national assessment be made of the number of people with a psychiatric disability who require home and community care services; the Department of Human Services and Health provide reports on studies undertaken on the relationship between socioeconomic status and mental health; and educational institutions and professional bodies be encouraged to emphasise training for general practitioners, nurses, psychologists and other community workers, including police and teachers, in psychiatric illness.
Time does not allow me to complete the tabling statement. I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 4.crisis teams be recognised as an important component of emergency care
5.where hospitals do not already produce reports on admissions/re-admissions of people with psychiatric illness they do so annually
6.various reports be made available by the Department of Human Services and Health on re-admissions as a result of failure to take medication and shortage of support services
7.training of GP's at undergraduate and graduate level involve raising awareness of services including psychology and psychiatric services
8.monitoring of the effects of education of prescribers about adverse affects and about the level of prescription of some substances
9.psychiatric health teams should be multi-disciplinary
10.research be continued on comparisons between the prescription by general practitioners and by psychiatrists of psychotherapeutic medications.

11.the importance of the pharmacists role be recognised and that the Commonwealth examine ways in which pharmacists can become more involved in monitoring and review of psychiatric medication prescribed in the community.
SERVICES FOR SPECIFIC GROUPS

The Committee found major deficiencies in current service provision to people of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander background, people of Non-English Speaking background, including recently arrived migrants (especially those suffering trauma because of war, torture etc), lower socio-economic groups, and some of the longer established Non-English Speaking background groups whose members may now be experiencing later life problems and other groups (including those with war service).

The Health system seems to have failed these groups of people—it certainly has not understood adequately their problems nor responded to the diverse health-related beliefs, attitudes and practices which are part of the culture of so many Australians.
The Committee has recommended that

1.annual reports be provided under the National Mental Health Strategy on the provision of services for people of non-English speaking and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander background and that estimates be made of the number of people requiring and obtaining such services and of the development of appropriate new services.

2.specialist teams be established as a matter of priority to meet the needs of people of non-English speaking background and that funding continue to be specifically devoted to developing teams and services to meet the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

3.both community and hospital psychiatric health services take all measures necessary to provide culturally and linguistically appropriate services, especially where these will help limit inappropriate service provision.
.Young People

The needs of young people with psychiatric illness may have been overlooked to a greater extent than those of people in other age groups. The Mental Health Workforce Committee has estimated that some 165,000 persons aged 9 to 17 years are affected by a serious mental illness in Australia. Other studies suggest that some 15% of adolescents `experience some form of mental health problem' and that `more than one % have serious psychiatric disorders which warrant specialist intervention—other research puts the figures higher.
Depression is on the increase among the young, which is reflected in the youth suicide rate. This, in turn, may be related to illicit drug use.
As such the Committee has recommended that
both community and residential psychiatric health services identify the specific needs of young people in their service area and develop strategies to meet these needs.
.Homeless people

Several reports to the Committee stated that there is a clear relationship between psychiatric illness and homelessness. Although the Committee does not doubt this, it believes that the relationship is a very complex one and that there is insufficient data and information to illuminate the problems of homelessness and mental illness.

Nevertheless, the Committee considers that appropriate housing is a particular need for people with psychiatric disabilities especially where this is compounded by factors which put the individual at risk. Certainly the Committee believes that where medication is the appropriate therapy, it is more likely to be effective when the patient is in a secure environment.
In view of this, the Committee has recommended that
1.appropriate accommodation services be a priority for people with psychiatric illness
2.there be an assessment of the number of people with psychiatric disability using Supported Accommodation and Assistance Program Services.
. Older people with mental illness and/or dementia, people with intellectual disabilities

There are some issues of concern relating to the prescription and/or use of psychotherapeutic medication for people whose major disability may be perceived by others to be disturbing behaviour. These people include:
people with intellectual disabilities
people with brain injury
aged people.
One submission stated:

Older people with mental illnesses and /or dementia are a particularly vulnerable group of psychotropic medication consumers. Anti-depressant medication is used widely to treat depression in the elderly, and alternative methods of treatment, such as psychotherapy, are seldom available. The major tranquillisers are frequently used as a chemical restraint for people with dementia whose behaviour is seen as `difficult', in settings such as public hospitals, Special Accommodation Houses and nursing homes, as well as at home. "Less restrictive environments" are frequently all but unavailable for the very confused person, who is likely to find him or herself in a locked environment (either within or outside the state psychiatric system) taking regular anti-psychotic medication and with an administrator managing financial matters.
Another submission stated:

The common prescription of psychotropic medication for those with developmental disability appears based more on custom than on empirical study, and driven by the belief that such drugs are effective in `quietening' patients who evidence disturbed and/or disturbing behaviours, akin to the general hospital or nursing home practice of prescribing `sleeping tablets'.

The shortage of staff in residential services—including those in the community—and the lack of other assistance for families who have the responsibility of caring for people with disabilities at home—may well make medication an attractive choice. However, it is not necessarily a choice which benefits the affected individual.
The Senate Community Affairs Committee has recommended that:

both community and residential psychiatric health services identify the specific needs of special groups such as older people, and the homeless in their service area and develop strategies to meet these needs.
.Rural and remote areas
With respect to rural and remote areas, the Committee supports the emphasis on the National Mental Health Strategy.

While limited information was received by the Committee from rural areas, a shortage of experienced medical staff was indicated with problems of inexperienced prescribing (leading to drug dependency) and much of the attention given to people with mental illness being handled by GP's.
The Senate Community Affairs References Committee has recommended that
there be a specific program to facilitate the awareness of psychiatric illness in rural, regional and remote communities.
A LACK OF EMPOWERMENT OF PATIENTS AND ADVOCACY SERVICES
Psychiatric illness is still very misunderstood in the community. Because of the stigma attached to it, such illness is probably significantly under-reported and under-diagnosed.
Fortunately, there is a growing number of different sufferer support groups and advocacy organisations, but there is still an enormous level of secrecy and suspicion to be overcome.

There is a strong need for advocacy services. Many submissions drew attention to cases where both patients and families were ignored or not asked about their symptoms or preferences for treatment. Often initial prescribing of medication led to the patient being completely debilitated and unable to act or advocate for himself/herself. One submission stated:

A person who was having financial problems was admitted for the first time to a psychiatric hospital against his wishes as an Involuntary Patient. Despite his protests he was immediately given psychotropic medication even though a detailed psychiatric assessment had not been made.

The medication used gave him severe adverse reactions and urgent medical treatment was required to overcome his life threatening reactions. Despite this occurrence he was still assessed during this 24 hour period, given a diagnosis and a treatment regime planned.
It is worth noting that the consumer could not participate in the process, or respond to any questions as the severe reaction meant that he was constantly gagging on a swollen tongue.
The unfortunate consumer was naturally frightened and unwilling to comply with further medical treatment. Within a short period he was returned to the community, but on a Community Treatment Order.
This type of story was unfortunately very common amongst the submissions received.
Further, many argued that patients are not given any choice or information about their treatment, neither is their treatment subsequently adequately monitored.
The Committee has recommended that
1.research be undertaken into both the rights and responsibilities of services providers and users
2.projects should address the psycho-social needs of the community which identify key issues in the consumer rights area
3.both community and hospital/institutional services develop a range of therapies and services which meet the needs of the community
4.the Government examine ways in which access to clinical and counselling psychologists can be improved
5.any development of mental health care services ensure that community-based services include a range of staff to address the needs of communities for therapies other than medication
As Chairman of the Senate Committee on Community Affairs, I commend this report on Psychotherapeutic Medication in Australia to the Chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to introduce amendments to the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Act 1985, the Wool International Act 1993 and the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993.

The amendment to the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Act 1985 allows for a system of fees and charges to be instituted for the processed foods industry which are in accordance with that industry's wishes.

AQIS develops charging methodology and fee levels after consultation with relevant industry groups. Recent consultation with the processed foods industry has confirmed that it wishes to continue with the current mix of charges applying to that program.
The proposed amendments correct some minor anomalies and provide a more appropriate legislative basis for meeting industry's wishes.

There are two amendments to the Wool International Act 1993. The first of these is to make special arrangements for the registration of low value sales. Under the present act, Wool International is required to keep a register of all wool-tax payers. The register will become the basis for the issue of equity in Wool International when it is eventually privatised.

Experience has shown the upkeep of the register involves the registration of a significant number of low value sales. The industry is concerned that the cost of recording these low value transactions and issuing annual statements will be very significant relative to the worth of the tax accruing from them.

At the request of the Wool Council of Australia, other wool industry representatives and Wool International, the government has agreed to make provision in the Act for the regulations to specify an amount for individual transactions below which Wool International would not be required to automatically register the transaction. However, if a person asks Wool International to include such a payment on the register, Wool International must do so. A request may relate to payments made between the date of the regulation and the time of the request.

The second proposed amendment to the Wool International Act 1993 relates to information held by Wool International on carpet wool-tax payers. The purpose of the amendment is to allow the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation (AWRAP) to obtain access to the information held by Wool International on the tax payer. AWRAP will require the consent of the carpet wool-tax payer to obtain the information, in the same way that information in respect of other wool-tax payers is obtained by AWRAP from Wool International. The information may only be used to determine eligibility to attend, and voting rights at, annual general meetings of awrap.
There are two amendments to the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993.

The first of these is to remove the present requirement that AWRAP Board meetings be held within Australia. The reason for the amendment is that the operations of AWRAP have been amalgamated with those of the International Wool Secretariat to provide a more focused wool promotion and research and development effort. The Board of AWRAP has been appointed to the board of the International Wool Secretariat. There will be occasions where it is appropriate that the Board of AWRAP meets overseas in conjunction with meetings of the International Wool Secretariat. Accordingly, the Chairman of AWRAP has asked the government to remove the existing restriction on where Board meetings may be held.

The second proposed amendment relates to the matching of payments made by the Commonwealth to AWRAP for research and development. At present, matching payments are not to exceed certain limits within the financial year. One of these limits is the amount paid to the Organisation by way of income from the collections made under the wool tax acts for wool research and development. The effect of the amendment will be to allow the Commonwealth to match expenditure in subsequent years from tax collections where these are not all spent in the year of collection. The ceiling for the commonwealth's matching of expenditure in any one year will remain at 0.5 per cent of the gross value of shorn wool produced in australia in the financial year.
I commend the bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition parties were quick to advise me that they would not support the inquiry. I did appeal to them, through Senator Ellison, the chairman of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee, to put principle above party loyalty to the Kennett government and its questionable practices, but to no avail. PARA.TAB: The answer from the government took a little longer. According to Attorney-General Lavarch, my terms of reference for the proposed inquiry have `the appearance of a direct interference by the Commonwealth in state affairs'. The Attorney-General also went into some detail about the fact that the procedures followed by the Commonwealth DPP have been well and truly scrutinised. His letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: On no occasion has the Commonwealth Attorney-General ever sought to exert direct or indirect political pressure upon the DPP in the exercise of his powers and functions under the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983. Various safeguards imposed by the DPP Act guard against impropriety in the form of political interference in the exercise of the prosecutorial discretion. I am prepared to concede that these provisions indeed form some sort of safeguard at Commonwealth level. They obviously do not exist at state level, certainly not in the state of Victoria. Since the Commonwealth Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, rejects supporting my reference to the committee on the ground that there is nothing untoward in the area of the Commonwealth DPP, I believe I should point out that all this ignores the fact that I was really only using the Commonwealth DPP's office as a reference point.

PARA.TAB: In fact, I do not know of any major problems concerning the Commonwealth DPP. On the contrary, prima facie, a lot of evidence is on the record that the discretion of the Commonwealth DPP is well exercised. The fact does remain that it is the Victorian DPP, the events in Victoria and the changes to the Victorian act that really are the nub of the concern. These concerns have been well publicised. There have been allegations that pressure has been exercised by Ms Wade, the Victorian Attorney-General, on behalf of Mr Kennett on Mr Bongiorno, the then DPP, to desist in his apparent intention to prosecute Mr Kennett on a matter of contempt of court regarding some remarks he made about a case that was then in progress.

Apart from these allegations, we have had amendments to the DPP legislation in Victoria which limit the independence—the discretion—of the DPP. Without going into those details, it has been suggested—again, it is only an allegation—that some of these amendments were intended to lay the ground for enabling the government to discontinue proceedings against Mr Elliott, a former President of the Liberal Party. I am saying that these are allegations, but it is important that these allegations be investigated and disposed of, if they can be disposed of, because they are serious allegations.

That is not all. We continue to the next event, which is the sacking of Mr Doug Meagher QC, who was in charge of preparing the prosecution case against members of the Victorian police force relating to the shooting of Mr Jensen. Mr Meagher had worked assiduously on that brief for some two years. Mr Meagher was sacked by the new DPP without any public explanation. Lo and behold, several weeks later, the new DPP, Mr Flatman, discontinued the prosecution case against those members of the Victorian police force. These are the matters that directly relate to the concerns about the DPP's office.

There is also a trend in Victoria that needs to be examined; that is, the obvious contempt with which the Victorian government, the Kennett government, treats the principle of separation of powers, which is at the base of the DPP issue. The right of appeal for ordinary citizens against government action under a particular piece of legislation is one of the safeguards of our democratic system. The Victorian parliament has always had the power to limit or prevent courts from reviewing decisions made by public servants or government offices, but with past governments the situation has usually been that the upper house has been controlled by the opposition—certainly, that was the case with the last Labor government. Therefore, there was a check on the government attempting to give itself powers regardless of what an individual citizen might wish to challenge about a government's actions under a particular piece of legislation. In the current situation, there is no such limitation. The Kennett government has an absolute majority in both houses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Galls you, doesn't it?

—Senator O'Chee, I agree with your expression of regret. Unfortunately, there is no Senate in Victoria and no Democrats in the Senate. If there were, Mr Kennett would not be able to get away with his utter contempt for the rights of ordinary citizens. Certainly, the present situation gives much impetus to the need for reform of the electoral system of the upper house in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps we could take a leaf out of New Zealand's book. New Zealand's recent reform saw proportional representation being introduced into the lower house. Let us take it step by step. For a start, we obviously need an upper house that is capable of an adequate and effective review of government action. I had occasion during the middle of last year to give notice of a motion to the Senate which listed 31 Victorian acts under which the Kennett government had proceeded to exclude any appeals to the Supreme Court. Events and statistics have progressed since then. I am informed that there are now 100 pieces of legislation in Victoria in which the Kennett government has proceeded to exclude appeals to the Supreme Court.

I will give an example. Residents of Albert Park have complained that the compacting process for the Formula 1 racetrack has led to structural damage and cracks in their houses. Normally, they would be able to take legal action to redress that situation and to claim compensation, but not under the Kennett government in Victoria. Their individual rights have been taken away. As a result of clauses of the Australian Grand Prix Bill, the Supreme Court is prevented from awarding compensation relating to the Grand Prix. Rather than the courts determining the issue, Premier Kennett has said that the payment of any compensation will be at his discretion.

The residents of Albert Park are not alone in having their rights taken away. There is, as I have said, a list of acts where this has been done which now extends to some 100 which have been passed by the Victorian parliament. We are looking at legislation such as the Commercial Arbitration (Amendment) Bill, the Murray-Darling Basin Bill, the Local Government (General Amendment) Bill, the Victorian Plantations Corporation Bill, the Land Titles Validation Bill, the Building Bill, the Planning and Environment (Amendment) Bill and various education acts. So the list goes on—I think it extends across the whole gamut of concerns that the community might have.

It has reached a proportion that has caused the judges of the Supreme Court to warn that legislation limiting their power to review government decisions has the potential to increase corruption. In their annual report, tabled in parliament, the judges said that such legislation deprives people of their normal legal rights and does not reflect equality before the law. They also warned that it vested judicial power in people not independent of the executive and limited the court's jurisdiction.

The judges identified two areas where state legislation had eroded the court's jurisdiction most severely. The first related to the vesting of power in ministers to make decisions which affect the rights of people, in conjunction with the limitation or removal of the court's jurisdiction to review such decisions. The second related to a number of instances where legislation has conferred on governments, government bodies, individuals and corporations immunity from the consequences of their actions. Conferring immunity and excluding or limiting the court's jurisdiction deprived citizens of compensation and other remedies under the law, while providing privileges for those protected under the legislation. The report said:

SPEECH.PARA: This does not reflect equality. When . . . legislation of this kind is passed without proper justification, the parliament weakens the rule of law. Such legislation can create arbitrary power, inequality under the law and increase the risk of corruption.

Here we have the judges of the Supreme Court putting on public record that we are in the process in Victoria of dismantling the basic safeguards which citizens are entitled to under the principle of separation of powers.

PARA.TAB: I could go on at length about other examples, but I shall desist for the moment. However, I will say that, since I have been informed that neither the opposition parties nor the government is prepared to take action to safeguard the basic democratic rights of Victorian citizens—that, in fact, they are prepared to forsake them and to leave them in the lurch—I think one must make yet another attempt to tackle the issue and I propose to do it in a different way.

If the government says that it is not prepared to look at specific instances of the misuse of government power that can be ascribed to the Kennett government, and if the opposition parties say they will protect one of their own, Mr Kennett, to wit, no matter what he or his government does, then let me foreshadow a motion to refer to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee a much more general question. I believe that it is a question that relates to the Australian constitution. The question is whether citizens that live under state governments should not have the same guarantees, the same safeguards, that are offered to Australian citizens under the provisions of the Australian constitution which vests judicial power in the High Court.

I believe that the matter which should be investigated by the committee—and I foreshadow that I will move such a reference for an inquiry—is to investigate whether it is advisable that the following should be put to the Australian community, as a referendum to change the Australian constitution: firstly, the vesting of the state judicial power exclusively in the Supreme Court of each state and such lesser courts as may be created. The vesting should be identical in its effect to the vesting of Commonwealth judicial power in the High Court and such federal courts as may be created.

Secondly, to ensure the independence of the legal profession, the power to admit barristers and solicitors to practise should be vested in the Supreme Court of each state, that right being subject to rules and regulations as the court may impose. This should give a right to practise not only in the particular state but anywhere else in Australia. Such right should be capable of revocation under the usual terms and provisions relating to misconduct and so on.

Thirdly, whether we should consider the creation in the constitution of the specific office of Attorney-General for each state with a prohibition on any other ministerial office being held, and with such tenure, rights and powers as the committee may find desirable but of which the duty to uphold the law by its enforcement is paramount. That is a fairly revolutionary suggestion, but very clearly the political aspects of the office of the first law officer of the state or the Commonwealth are such that it has—certainly in Victoria—damaged severely the individual safeguards and rights of citizens.

Finally, the inquiry would look at the creation in the constitution of the specific office of Director of Public Prosecutions for each state with a prohibition on any other office being held, with such tenure, rights and powers as the committee may find desirable but of which the duty to enforce the criminal law by prosecution is paramount.

I believe that these are matters which are exceedingly important for every Australian citizen. They have been brought to light by events in Victoria. Since neither the government nor the coalition parties is prepared to look at those events, I will challenge them to look at the substantive constitutional issues which I believe the Senate needs to consider. The best place to start is with an inquiry by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1993 the Attorney-General approved a steering committee to conduct a comprehensive review of the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions. The committee examined all aspects of the operational environment of the DPP including the role of the Attorney-General in the conduct of the prosecution process.

PARA.TAB: The review was conducted over a period of seven months during which time members of the steering committee consulted all regional offices of the DPP and interviewed all state directors of public prosecutions. The committee considered in detail the practices and procedures of prosecuting authorities in other countries such as the US, the UK and also Canada. The report of the review was released in March 1994 and the steering committee determined that the current legislative arrangements defining the role of the Attorney-General in the conduct of the prosecution process were appropriate and that there was no basis for reviewing those arrangements.

There has been no instance at Commonwealth level of the Attorney-General attempting to exert direct or indirect political pressure upon the DPP in the exercise of his powers and functions. The power of direction exercisable by the Attorney-General under the DPP Act is rarely used and has never been used in relation to a specific case. Various safeguards imposed by the legislation guard against impropriety in the form of political interference in the exercise of the prosecutorial discretion. The Attorney-General is required to consult with the DPP prior to issuing any directions under the DPP Act. Furthermore, any directions issued under the act are required to be published and laid before parliament.

The Commonwealth DPP Act achieves an appropriate balance between independence and accountability and, accordingly, it is neither necessary nor desirable in the public interest to embark upon an inquiry into the independence of the DPP at Commonwealth level. If such an inquiry is not justifiable at Commonwealth level, an inquiry based upon the terms of reference proposed by Senator Spindler does, of course, have the appearance of a direct interference in state matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean, `an appearance'? It is true. You are being too generous to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to pay tribute to an old friend of mine, the Reverend Edgar Wells. It is appropriate that I should be doing it at this time because he was one of the people who—long before anyone else in the church or very many people in the nation—were concerned about the whole issue of Aboriginal land rights. He was a man who fought both the church and the government of the day in order to represent the people in Arnhem Land amongst whom he had been a missionary for some years.

PARA.TAB: Edgar Wells was born in Lincoln, England, in 1908 and he died on 4 May 1995 aged 86 years. In the 1970s the Reverend Wells helped me understand the situation of Aboriginal people in Australia in a way that I had not understood before despite my contact during the 1960s and the 1970s with them in Mitchell and Cloncurry in Queensland. I had much to learn, even though I had had extensive contact with Aboriginals.

Edgar Wells was one of those people who pointed me towards questions which I had never faced before about oppression and the injustice perpetrated upon Aboriginal people. I want to pay tribute by reading into the record some of the obituary which appeared in today's Australian, as well as the record which is in the minutes of the Methodist conference in 1973 when Edgar Wells retired from the active ministry of the Methodist church. The Australian records this about his life:

SPEECH.PARA: Edgar Wells was one of the last of the old men associated with the famous 1963 `bark petition' of the Yirrkala people to the federal government for land rights. He was a white man, a missionary, whom the Aboriginal people of Arnhem Land called `Bapa (father) Wells'.

PARA.TAB: He was an integral figure in the struggle of the Yirrkala people, a compassionate man who came as much to learn as to convert. He was one of the very few white people to witness secret Aboriginal ceremonies, one of the first missionaries to bring Aboriginal symbols inside the church, and he did not separate children from their parents as so many missionaries did.
The Aboriginal elder Wandjak said in 1976: `The Wellses were the only missionaries who really wanted to help the Aborigines'.
Mandawuy Yunupingu, the Yothu Yindi singer who was a young boy when Wells ministered at Yirrkala, last week described Wells as `a gentle person'.

`Bapa Wells was involved in setting a precedent in creating an awareness to the federal government and the people of Australia of Aboriginal peoples' right to their land and how mining companies should respond to traditional Aboriginal landowners,' Yunupingu said.

`He stood firm with the Aboriginal people in making sure that our elders' voice was being heard and that our political and spiritual integrity was not taken away from us. We say thank you, Bapa, and thank you for your kindness.'

SPEECH.PARA: The story of Yirrkala is the story of the modern struggle of the Aboriginal people. The obituary continues:
Prospectors had discovered bauxite in Arnhem Land in 1951, and the Northern Territory government responded by legalising mining in the Arnhem Land reserve.

PARA.TAB: In February 1963 the Prime Minister, Robert Menzies, announced that the Gove development, a $50 million mining project would go ahead in Arnhem Land, which entailed excising most of the 51,800ha Yirrkala reserve. Wells was appalled. The quietly spoken churchman sent a dramatic telegram to the leaders of the Methodist church, nine leading newspapers and others. It said: `583 semi-nomads now squeezed by the bauxite land grab into half a square mile stop impossible to house population in approved homes within area stop . . . loss of cultivated and grazing lands means we must eat the cattle before the miners arrive and import basic food crops afterwards.'

Independently, the Yolngu people began their historic protest. They wrote letters, not arguing there should be no mining, but arguing their right to be consulted about what mining should take place and under what terms.

In July 1963, two federal Labor MPs, Kim Beazley snr and Gordon Bryant, visited Yirrkala and learned the Yolngu wanted to petition the Prime Minister. In Wells' church, with its Aboriginal paintings in the sanctuary, Beazley conceived the idea that the petition be a bark painting. It was presented the following month. Stating that much of the area was sacred, the petition said: `From time immemorial, we were all born here'.

While Wells had deliberately played no part in the drawing up of the petition, he was suspected of `agitating' and it made him enemies in the church and wider community. In June 1963 Wells told Cecil Gribble, general secretary of the Methodist Overseas Mission at Yirrkala: `The history of mining in the colonial empire leads me to believe that under no circumstances can the mining industry be trusted to secure any but their own interests.'

SPEECH.PARA: The House of Representatives committee which met heard evidence from Wells, and eventually he was transferred by the Methodist church from the mission. He refused to go, but eventually he was dismissed and sent south. Not a proud record for the church, but one which began a very steep learning curve for the Methodist and later the Uniting Church. It was not until 1993, however, that the Uniting Church, in an act of belated contrition, recognised Edgar Wells's 15 years of work with the Yolngu people of Yirrkala and Milingimbi.

PARA.TAB: I wish to read a little from the church's own tribute to him when he retired. It reads in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Wells had several moves around Queensland, but there was developing within him a growing concern for the Aborigines. As a result, in 1949, he offered and was accepted for service in the Northern Territory under the direction of Overseas Missions. After a year in Sydney when he was under Professor A P Elkin at the Sydney University, he was appointed to the Milingimbi Mission Station. Here he exercised a most effective and satisfying ministry in those critical and restless post-war years.

We also pay tribute to his wife who worked with him for many years in his missionary work. She was a nursing sister, a women's craft supervisor and weather and wireless dispatch officer. She worked with her husband in this area.

PARA.TAB: When they retired they retained a strong interest in Aboriginal affairs and, as I said, they had an influence on me in forcing me to ask many questions that I had not asked before. Their experience and wealth of knowledge of the area were frequently sought and most readily given to many people in and outside the church. I am honoured to be able to pay this tribute to Edgar Wells and to offer my condolences to his family.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the number of reported incidents of anti-semitism in each State and Territory of Australia for the years 1990 to 1995? Please break down the data per State/Territory and per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) My Department does not collect any statistics which would allow it to provide this information.

An officer of my Department has consulted the Executive Director of the National Police Ethnic Advisory Bureau on the matter and the Bureau has, in turn, canvassed the views of State/Territory police forces around Australia. They have advised that they do not keep statistics on incidents of a racist nature and are thus unable to assist. Several responses have pointed out the difficulty of collecting such statistics when there is no offence in the criminal code which specifically relates to such an occurrence.
Both the Institute of Criminology and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission have also been consulted, but have been unable to assist with the detailed information required.

However the Race Discrimination Unit of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission pointed to the Report of the National Inquiry into Racist Violence in Australia (AGPS, 1991). Appendix 14, Part 4 of that Report tabulates alleged incidents of Racist Violence against Jewish People, as reported to the Inquiry. It indicates that, during the period 1990-1991 (when the Inquiry was conducted), two incidents were reported as having taken place, both in NSW.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 4 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the cost to the Government of the seminar conducted in Parliament House, Canberra on 27 and 28 March 1995, which the department sponsored.
(2) What invitations were issued to federal parliamentarians to attend.

(3) Why is it that of the 45 participants included in the agenda there were no less than 9 Australian Labor Party (ALP) politicians, an ALP mayor and at least one is an ALP candidate, and no representatives from any other political parties.

(4) Why was it that, apart from a minor role for 2 officers from the New South Wales and Western Australian planning departments, no State Government, other than the Queensland Government, appears to have been involved.
(5) Is it a fact that no State ministers spoke, nor were they or any representatives listed on the official agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Better Cities: Urban Change in Action seminar is expected to cost close to $85,000.

(2) The Better Cities: Urban Change in Action seminar was a public seminar, open to the public and publicly advertised in the Canberra Times on 23, 24 and 25 March 1995. As such, the seminar was open to all members of parliament who wished to attend. Invitations were extended to members of the Government to participate in the seminar due to a long standing interest in the program amongst the majority of Caucus members.

The exhibition was open to the public as well as members of parliament. In addition to the Canberra Times, advertisements included an announcement on the ABC's Meet the Press Program. One of the purposes of holding the exhibition in Parliament House was to afford members of parliament a convenient opportunity to view the achievements to date of the Better Cities program.

(3) The participants in the seminar were drawn from a wide range of parliamentary, public and private sector backgrounds, representing most States and Territories. The main speakers included four Federal Members of Parliament, five Commonwealth and State departmental officers, three Local Government officers, three statutory authority Chief Executive Officers, two private sector representatives and two academics. Also participating were the Executive Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Director, Australian Urban and Regional Development Review.
All participants were invited to address the seminar in order to share the experience and knowledge they have of the issues involved in urban design or their involvement in the Better Cities program.

(4) Planning Ministers from all States and Territories were invited to participate in the seminar. The Hon Richard Lewis MLA, the Western Australian Minister for Planning and Heritage, could not attend but was represented by the Hon Ian Osborne MLA. Due to parliamentary elections in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, the Planning Ministers were not known and therefore invitations were not extended. The remaining Planning Ministers were unable to attend due to other commitments.

Over the first three years of the Better Cities program, the Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments, have developed a very successful and cooperative working relationship in regard to the implementation of the program.

(5) In the light of the response to Question 4 above, it is a fact that no State minister or their representatives spoke or were listed on the official agenda. The only Federal Minister invited to speak was the Minister responsible for the program, the Minister for Housing and Regional Development.
